course_title: (ACECCE) Programme for Toddlers
course_title_cleaned: (ACECCE) Programme for Toddlers
course_objective: There are profound differences between toddlers and preschoolers. There should not be a one size programme that fits both toddlers and preschoolers as such programme will be too large and too impersonal to toddlers. This module focuses on the components of a quality programme for toddlers in group care and how to provide for their needs, growth, and interests day to day. The importance of the educator's role, building relationships with children and parents, teaching approaches and techniques, materials, methods for developing ageappropriate curriculum and setting up learning environments will be included. Students will also learn how to plan; design and present activities for areas of the toddler curriculum based on observations of their development and needs.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of the module, participants should have:

1. The ability to understand:
a. Developmental theories
b. Developmental stages of children from birth to age 3
c. Different areas of children’s growth and development
d. Expected milestones (developmental stages) across different aspects of
children’s growth and development
e. Strategies to support children’s holistic development
f. A range of teaching, learning and care giving approaches that meet the needs of young children
g. The relevant Curriculum Frameworks utilised in Singapore
h. How children learn concepts through sensory experiences, exploration, play, interactions and inquiry

2. The ability to:
a. Contribute to planning and implementation of teaching, learning and care-giving approaches, taking into account the developmental stages and backgrounds of children
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have:
a. 3 GCE ‘O’ level credits including a grade C6 in GCE ‘O’ level English Language OR Any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
OR
b. 10 years of formal education and passed state exam with credits in 3 different subjects including a credit at least C6 in EL1 or any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
full_course_desc:
# course provider
KLC INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE PTE. LTD.

# course title
(ACECCE) Programme for Toddlers

# course url
/content/portal/en/training-exchange/course-directory/course-detail.html?courseReferenceNumber=TGS-2024045290

# course duration
3-5 days

# course mode of training
Full Time and Part Time

# full course fee
$385.00

# subsidised course fee
$115.50

# course number of hours
35.00 hours

# course language
English

# course objective
There are profound differences between toddlers and preschoolers. There should not be a one size programme that fits both toddlers and preschoolers as such programme will be too large and too impersonal to toddlers. This module focuses on the components of a quality programme for toddlers in group care and how to provide for their needs, growth, and interests day to day. The importance of the educator's role, building relationships with children and parents, teaching approaches and techniques, materials, methods for developing ageappropriate curriculum and setting up learning environments will be included. Students will also learn how to plan; design and present activities for areas of the toddler curriculum based on observations of their development and needs.

# course learning outcomes
At the end of the module, participants should have:

1. The ability to understand:
a. Developmental theories
b. Developmental stages of children from birth to age 3
c. Different areas of children’s growth and development
d. Expected milestones (developmental stages) across different aspects of
children’s growth and development
e. Strategies to support children’s holistic development
f. A range of teaching, learning and care giving approaches that meet the needs of young children
g. The relevant Curriculum Frameworks utilised in Singapore
h. How children learn concepts through sensory experiences, exploration, play, interactions and inquiry

2. The ability to:
a. Contribute to planning and implementation of teaching, learning and care-giving approaches, taking into account the developmental stages and backgrounds of children

# course entry req
Applicants should have:
a. 3 GCE ‘O’ level credits including a grade C6 in GCE ‘O’ level English Language OR Any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
OR
b. 10 years of formal education and passed state exam with credits in 3 different subjects including a credit at least C6 in EL1 or any English Language Acceptable Alternatives

course_title: (ACECCE-E) Demonstrate Understanding of the Centre's Vision, Mission and Values (Infant/Toddler Educarer, Beginning Educarer)
course_title_cleaned: (ACECCE-E) Demonstrate Understanding of the Centre's Vision, Mission and Values (Infant Toddler Educarer, Beginning Educarer)
course_objective: Sound practice in the provision of education and care is grounded in clear understanding of local cultural and historical contexts as well as knowledge of global developments. Basic understanding of what educating young children is all about is important as these factors determine the quality of experiences that will be provided for them by teachers of young children. This module will trace the historical roots and influences on early childhood education, gives an overview of growth, policies, licensing requirements, quality, role and status of early childhood care and education in Singapore.  Vision, mission and values are of core importance as they form the core ideas of practices in the centres. This module explores the centres’ vision, mission, and values, and its alignment with the curriculum and programmes. It also encourages participants on contributing to foster a culture that promote the mission, vision and values.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of the module, participants should have:

1. The ability to understand:
a. An overview of the development of and perspectives on early childhood care and education
b. Overview of Singapore’s early childhood education
c. Philosophy and Goals of Early Childhood Programmes
d. Policies, licensing requirements, teacher certification and training requirements in Singapore
e. The centre’s vision, mission and values
f. The rationale behind the centre’s vision, mission and values and its long term direction
g. How own actions can affect the centre’s objectives

2. The ability to:
a. Articulate the rationale behind the vision, mission and values of the centre
b. Align daily practice to the centre’s vision, mission and values
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have:
a. 3 GCE ‘O’ level credits including a grade C6 in GCE ‘O’ level English Language OR Any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
OR
b. 10 years of formal education and passed state exam with credits in 3 different subjects including a credit at least C6 in EL1 or any English Language Acceptable Alternatives

course_title: Mastering Design Thinking - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Creative Technologist Fundamentals (SDCT)
course_title_cleaned: Mastering Design Thinking - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Creative Technologist Fundamentals (SDCT)
course_objective: The Mastering Design Thinking module is a comprehensive and immersive course that empowers students to excel in the realm of design thinking. Going beyond the basics, this module explores the depths of creativity and equips students with essential skills to become proficient problem solvers and innovative thinkers. Through a human-centred approach, students will learn to empathize with users, redefine problems, and generate ground-breaking solutions. With a focus on pushing the boundaries of creativity and advancing design thinking frameworks, this module prepares students to tackle diverse real-world challenges and make a meaningful impact.
course_learning_outcomes: Mastering Design Thinking - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Creative Technologist Fundamentals (SDCT) is a 90hrs module.
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have a relevant local polytechnic diploma (Refer to list below)
Nanyang Polytechnic
Diploma in Experiential Product & Interior Design 
Diploma in Architecture (Professional Competency Model)

Ngee Ann Polytechnic
Diploma in Design
Diploma in Media Post-Production

Republic Polytechnic
Diploma in Digital Design and Development
Diploma in Engineering Design with Business
Diploma in Media Production and Design
Diploma in Design for User Experience

Singapore Polytechnic
Diploma in Architecture
Diploma in Interior Design
Diploma in Media, Arts and Design

Temasek Polytechnic
Diploma in Interior Architecture and Design
Diploma in Product Experience & Design

course_title: MASTER OF ARTS (EDUCATIONAL LEADERSHIP)
course_title_cleaned: MASTER OF ARTS (EDUCATIONAL LEADERSHIP)
course_objective: The Master of Arts in Educational Management (MAEM) programme aims to enable you to develop the knowledge, skills and capability to your organisations effectively at a time of rapid change.   This programme is designed for individuals who hold management positions in the education service (e.g. principals, vice-principals, heads of department and teachers with positions of responsibility and MOE officers); as well as individuals with managerial experiences from other learning and training enterprises (e.g. military, nursing and other private and tertiary educational institutions).
course_learning_outcomes:
This programme pursues three broad aims:

1. To enable aspiring leaders in education to become more informed about critical issues in educational management, and thus to apply intellectual approaches to their work
2. To help them cope positively and effectively with the management challenges that are currently impacting on education
3. To enable them to acquire a recognised and valued postgraduate award.
course_entry_req: Bachelor

course_title: Project Management - Part of Modular Certificate in Site Management (DECS1)
course_title_cleaned: Project Management - Part of Modular Certificate in Site Management (DECS1)
course_objective: This module covers the principles of project management at various stages of building, execution of construction work on-site and off-site. It includes the knowledge to manage contract design specification, contractual agreement, competitive tendering, construction economics, claims and even disputes during the design, tender and construction phrases of a project. Students will also learn about the conditions of contract and contract administration of a project.
course_learning_outcomes: Project Management - Part of Modular Certificate in Site Management (DECS1) is a 60hrs module.
course_entry_req:
The following GCE ‘O’ Level grades and with at least 1 year of relevant work experience:
1. English Language (Grade 1-7)
2. Mathematics (Grade 1-6)
3. Science (Grade 1-6)
- OR NITEC with GPA >= 3.5
- OR NITEC with GPA >= 3.0 and with at least 1 year of relevant work experience
- OR Higher NITEC with GPA >= 2.0
- OR Higher NITEC with GPA >= 1.5 and with at least 1 year of relevant work experience
- OR NITEC in Technology or Services with GPA >= 3.5 and with at least 1 year of relevant working experience
- OR Higher NITEC in Technology or Services with GPA >=2.0 and with at least 1 year of relevant working experience
- OR relevant Advanced WSQ Certifi cate (or higher) and Level 6 WSQ Workplace Literacy SOA and Workplace Numeracy SOA and with at least 1 yearof relevant working experience
- OR applicants with at least 2 years of relevant working experience may apply for the course

course_title_cleaned: Structural Modelling - Part of Modular Certificate in Construction IT (DECS1)

# course objective
This module introduces students to BIM processes and applications. The students will be equipped with the practical 3D BIM structural modelling skills and technical knowledge to initiate projects using BIM. It also enables students to learn how to apply the e-submission guidelines and to understand the mandatory format for regulatory approval.

# course learning outcomes
Structural Modelling - Part of Modular Certificate in Construction IT (DECS1) is a 60hrs module.


# course entry req

3. Science (Grade 1-6)

course_title: Be a Sport Safety Champion (Synchronous elearning)
course_title_cleaned: Be a Sport Safety Champion (Synchronous elearning)
course_objective: As Sport Singapore strives to further the promotion of sports excellence and greater participation in sports, it also recognises that safety must be a fundamental component of the sporting culture. It endorses a shared belief that every individual should have the opportunity to play sports and do so responsibly in safe environments to prevent and reduce sports-related accidents. This course will equip learners with knowledge and skills to recognise common sport injuries and how to prevent injuries while exercising.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of this course, participants should be able to:
1. Recognise the common sport injuries and factors leading to it.
2. Identify types of reactive and preventive measures.
3. Ability to implement preventive measures and reduce the occurrence of injuries
course_entry_req: Basic English language proficiency and familiarity with MS Office applications

As Sport Singapore strives to further the promotion of sports excellence and greater participation in sports, it also recognises that safety must be a fundamental component of the sporting culture. It endorses a shared belief that every individual should have the opportunity to play sports and do so responsibly in safe environments to prevent and reduce sports-related accidents. This course will equip learners with knowledge and skills to recognise common sport injuries and how to prevent injuries while exercising.

course_title: (PDECCE-T) Set Up Quality Learning Environments (Beginning Pre-school Teacher)
course_title_cleaned: (PDECCE-T) Set Up Quality Learning Environments (Beginning Pre-school Teacher)
course_objective: Physical and social environments have profound effects on children’s development. Young children learn within the security of well-planned physical environments that support social interactions based upon respect and acceptance. space, accessibility to the outdoors, arrangement of rooms, availability of a variety of materials, air quality, equipment, and lighting play important roles in children’s well-being, learning and creativity.  Students will gain the ability to set up the learning environment purposefully, through interpretation of observations and documentation to provide engaging, stimulating and challenging learning experiences that support integrated learning and the curriculum. It also includes discussion of effective classroom management strategies to ensure minimal disruption to learning centre activities, curriculum delivery and learning.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of the module, participants should have:

1. The ability to understand:
a. Developmental stages of children from birth to age 6
b. Interests of children
c. Types of learning environments
    - Physical environment (both indoor and outdoor)
    - Temporal environment
    - Interactional environment
d. Features of a quality learning environment
e. Strategies to set up a quality learning environment that supports the curriculum
f. Strategies to interpret observations and documentation of children’s learning
g. A range of developmentally appropriate learning resources
h. The relationship between the types of learning environments
i. Classroom management strategies

2. The ability to:
a. Design the learning environment purposefully to provide engaging, stimulating and challenging learning experiences
b. Provide children with frequent and regular access to the outdoors (including opportunities to explore the natural environment)
c. Utilise developmentally appropriate learning resources to foster children’s learning
d. Utilise interpretation of observations and documentation to provide developmentally appropriate choices for children
e. Create a learning environment that supports integrated learning
f. Apply classroom management strategies to create an environment that is conducive to teaching and learning
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have:

*  5 GCE ‘O’ level credits including a grade C6 in GCE ‘O’ level English Language OR Any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
OR
*  10 years of formal education in English as a medium of instruction and passed state exam with credits in 5 different subjects OR required to pass English Language
OR
*  Degree with English as medium of instruction from state recognised university OR required to pass English Language Acceptable Alternatives

course_title: Art of Managing Risks for Project Excellence (SFw)
course_title_cleaned: Art of Managing Risks for Project Excellence (SFw)
course_objective: The effective management of project risks are critical to the success of the project and it proactively protects your organization from project incidents and matters that can affect the reputation and successful completion of project deliverables within the allocated budget and schedule.  This course covers the systematic process of identifying, assessing, and mitigating threats or uncertainties in project management that can greatly benefit your organization.
course_learning_outcomes: Learners will be able to explain the importance and benefits of risk management for projects; describe the risk management process and its key steps; apply the tools and techniques in risk management; identify, analyze, evaluate, prioritize, and treat project risks.
course_entry_req: It is recommended for the participants to have at least 1 year experience in project management.

course_title_cleaned: WSQ Frontline Management (L2) (AOP)
course_objective: The course focuses in elevating the HAs and PSAs’ competency level not only in dealing with daily frontline services such as patient registration, admission and discharge process, and appointment booking but also aims on enhancing the capabilities of the HAs and PSAs in area such as patient engagement and interaction, observing patient current medical conditions for medical triage and arranging necessary facilities and equipment prior to patients’ appointments.
course_learning_outcomes:
1. Introduction to types of patients and visitors during Pre-registration
2. Applying organisation procedures for patient registration and patient management systems
3. Patient service in frontline healthcare

course_title: Spice Odyssey CAPSTONE PROJECT
course_title_cleaned: Spice Odyssey CAPSTONE PROJECT
course_objective: This is the culmination of the 18-month programme that allows students to use all their learned skills and knowledge to create food and beverage products using of herbs and spices.  It is a group project that emphasizes on teamwork, professionalism, skills, knowledge, and creativity. course_title: A Caregiver’s Guide to the Palliative Care Approach
course_title_cleaned: A Caregiver’s Guide to the Palliative Care Approach
course_objective: This course aims to provide caregivers with an understanding of the palliative care approach and the knowledge to provide person-centred care to individuals living with life-limiting conditions.
course_learning_outcomes:
Learners will develop an understanding of the palliative care approach and how to provide person-centre care to the persons with life-limiting illness.

7 learning units will be delivered during the session:
1. The Essentials of the Palliative Care Approach
2. Person-centred Care
3. Enriching Lives
4. Communicating about Death
5. End-of-Life Care 
6. Resilient Caregiving
7. Palliative Care Resource

course_title: Developing and Engaging Your Team for Workplace Success (Synchronous E-Learning)
course_title_cleaned: Developing and Engaging Your Team for Workplace Success (Synchronous E-Learning)
course_objective: This course is designed to help managers, supervisors and aspiring leaders to develop and engage their teams for workplace success. Participants acquire knowledge of Tuckman's Phases of Team Development model, and the principles and strategies that can be applied for each stage, to optimize team performance.
course_learning_outcomes:
•	Understand the Tuckman's Phases of Team Development model
•	Recognize the characteristics and challenges of each stage
•	Develop strategies to effectively manage each stage of team development
•	Learn techniques to build team cohesion, trust, and communication
•	Identify and address common team dysfunctions
•	Practise team development and engagement exercises.
course_entry_req:
Open to all unemployed or employed Singaporeans and Singapore Permanent Residents who are looking for training opportunities to transit to a new sector or job role. Applicants must be committed to completing training and passing assessments.

Applicants should:
- Possess a positive attitude and apply the new skill they have gained back in their workplace
- Have at least 3 years of working experience in relevant roles
- Have obtained a diploma and above academic qualification
- Be able to operate a computer or laptop to perform basic tasks
- Applicants who do not meet these recommended requirements may be considered on a case-by-case basis

Open to all unemployed or employed Singaporeans and Singapore Permanent Residents who are looking for training opportunities to transit to a new sector or job role. Applicants must be committed to completing training and passing assessments.

Applicants should:
- Possess a positive attitude and apply the new skill they have gained back in their workplace
- Have at least 3 years of working experience in relevant roles
- Have obtained a diploma and above academic qualification
- Be able to operate a computer or laptop to perform basic tasks
- Applicants who do not meet these recommended requirements may be considered on a case-by-case basis

course_title: Mindfulness and Self Care for Healthy Ageing
course_title_cleaned: Mindfulness and Self Care for Healthy Ageing
course_objective: This module equip learners with the knowledge and skills on mindfulness and self care techniques to healthy ageing: •	Understanding mindfulness. •	Practice various mindfulness techniques. •	Practicing mindfulness to manage stress and overcome negativity •	Achieve calmness and relaxation through mindfulness exercises
course_learning_outcomes:
•	This skill describes the ability to use mindfulness and self care techniques to help in healthy ageing.
•	Core mindfulness skill can be taught and cultivated through established and innovative methods to introduce participants to the 3 essential qualities of this way of paying attention: 
(a) an active engagement of attention (i.e., purposefully/intentionally), 
(b) by coming back to what's happening in the present moment, patiently and repeatedly, and 
(c) in a manner that is open to noticing new information (i.e., flexibly and nonjudgmentally).

course_title: NSA -  Decoupage Art Course
course_title_cleaned: NSA -  Decoupage Art Course
course_objective: Participants will enjoy the fun and satisfaction of creating an art projects with their everyday used objects. Hence, decoupage is an art and skill of upcycling. Using the various techniques/skill of decoupage, the participants can decorate household items such as bags, pouch, glass bottles, porcelain plates, wooden boxes, to even large pieces of furniture which can be transformed to functional art pieces as gifts or for re-sale. The skills acquired could lead to entrepreneurial opportunities for participants.
course_learning_outcomes:
Session 1:
a)	Introduction to decoupage
b)	To decoupage on PVC pouch

Session 2: 
a)	To decoupage on fabric material

Session 3: 
a)	To decoupage on recycled material

Session 4: 
a)	To decoupage on glass bottle

Session 5:
a)	Teaching of crackle technique
b)	To decoupage on wooden material

Session 6:
a)	Teaching of 3-D pop-up technique
b)	To decoupage on wooden material


Session 7
a)	Teaching of lace design/technique
b)	To decoupage on canvas bag

Session 8:
a)	Teaching of reverse technique on glass
b)	To decoupage on a glass plate

course_title: NSA-  Joyful Edible Gardening - Growing with Resilience
course_title_cleaned: NSA-  Joyful Edible Gardening - Growing with Resilience
course_objective: This course aims to discuss the benefits of tending to edible plants, and how working with plants can build resilience in us.  Participants will brainstorm to come up with edible growing activities that will help adults to unwind while engaging their five senses, and reflect on challenges faced in a healthier manner.
course_learning_outcomes:
The pace of life has become faster than ever, and building mental resilience has been brought to the forefront in recent years. How do we build perseverance and support structures so that we move far away from being labelled the strawberry generation?

Edible growing can bring about many great benefits and help us to manage with stressors in life. Learn how you can include these activities into your day-to-day, and develop a stronger mind to persevere through life's challenges.

course_title: NSA- Speeches for Special Occasions
course_title_cleaned: NSA- Speeches for Special Occasions
course_objective: The course aims to impart learners with  (1)  the confidence to speak before an audience, (2) the proper speech structures to employ, (3) the appropriate speech contents, (4) the technical skills of speaking - eye contact, voice pitch, rate, and volume, hand gestures etc  and (5) how to engage the audience.
course_learning_outcomes: Seniors are often expected to speak on special occasions - to propose a toast at a banquet, to deliver a eulogy, to present an after-dinner speech, to roast an old friend, and to speak in praise of someone special. Many are embarrassed because they do not know where to start, what to say, and how to end the speech. course_title: Sense Making (Synchronous E-Learning)
course_title_cleaned: Sense Making (Synchronous E-Learning)
course_objective: Sense making is an essential process in daily life and even more so when candidates are managing teams and/or leading projects to ensure proactive and holistic consideration of current situations to assist then in maneuvering challenging obstacles, forecast different situations to propel forward planning and recovery, and provide an outlook that makes adequate sense for informed decisions. This course is designed for candidates who handles a huge amount of information daily and needs to synthesize them internally for to make informed decisions with extrapolated situation for preparation. Candidates will learn the different thinking processes and extrapolation techniques which will support them in making sense of the situation and their decisions.
course_learning_outcomes:
•	Perform analysis on data System Thinking Theories
•	Evaluate data to ensure appropriate usage for informed decisions
•	Make connections and formulate an action plan to manage the challenge in compliance with existing regulations
•	Reflect and extrapolate possible positive and negative impacts for enhancement and/or alteration
course_entry_req:
Open to all unemployed or employed Singaporeans and Singapore Permanent Residents who are looking for training opportunities to transit to a new sector or job role. Applicants must be committed to completing training and passing assessments.

Applicants should:
- Possess a positive attitude and apply the new skill they have gained back in their workplace
- Have at least 3 years of working experience in relevant roles
- Have obtained a diploma and above academic qualification
- Be able to operate a computer or laptop to perform basic tasks
- Applicants who do not meet these recommended requirements may be considered on a case-by-case basis

course_title: IMPLEMENT INDIVIDUALISED CARE PLAN IN THERAPY (CLASSROOM & SYNCHRONOUS)
course_title_cleaned: IMPLEMENT INDIVIDUALISED CARE PLAN IN THERAPY (CLASSROOM & SYNCHRONOUS)
course_objective: The Healthcare market in Singapore is developing a network of community care system to meet the changing and varied needs of the population, especially the seniors living in a rapidly ageing society. In tandem, a new healthcare need is emerging in the community care sector to help seniors live well and age gracefully at home and in the community.  In the community, there is a need to assist in Individualised care plans to be able to provide a higher standard of care and support for the patient/client. It is an important aspect of patient-centred care as it provides an organised structure for identifying patients’ needs for individualising care to those needs. This result in better patient/client outcomes.  This course enables the participants to have knowledge and skills to interpret individualised care plan and implement basic facilitation of therapeutic activities safely and effectively, including activity considerations and documentation of completed activities.
course_learning_outcomes:
In this course, the participants will learn to Interpret the individualised care plan and prioritise the therapeutic activities. They are able to provide basic facilitation during therapeutic activities safely and effectively, in accordance to organisational guidelines and personal competencies.
Participants learn to implement care plan with consideration to the possible challenges that may arise and able to document accordingly after completion of activities
course_entry_req:
•  Obtained at least a C6 pass at N-Level in any 1 subject or equivalent; OR
•  Workplace Literacy & Numeracy (WPLN) Level 4 (Speaking, Listening, Reading & Numeracy) and Level 3 (Writing)
•  Certified medically fit for healthcare training and work by approved clinics
•  Must clear HMI Institute’s admissions screening process for the course/programme
Applicants will be assessed by the Institute on their suitability for the course prior to enrolment. Academic qualifications are but one of several assessment criteria.

This will in turn help course participants to build strong managerial competencies for working effectively and efficiently in the restaurants and other food and beverage service establishments. b)	skills and knowledge to close the existing industry skills gap and match their future job roles in the food service sector. c)	transferable skills that they would need to work better and function effectively in their career in the food services sector. d)	qualification that they would continue to pursue a higher qualification in food services.
course_learning_outcomes: The Diploma in Beverage Management is a 12-month programme including a 6-month apprenticeship approved under the SSG funding agreement as SkillsFuture Career Transition Programmes (SCTPs).

•	Obtained at least an IELTS score of 5.5 / TOEFL (internet-based total) score of 46-59 / WPL Level 5;

Work Experience Required:

17

course_title: (SCTP) Visual Design (Classroom and Asynchronous)
course_title_cleaned: (SCTP) Visual Design (Classroom and Asynchronous)
course_objective: This course seeks to equip learners with the skills required to create content such as graphics, designs and layout for digital platforms. Learners will learn about the various design specifications and requirements of common digital platforms from social media to web. They will be introduced to aesthetic and design, colour and typography, vector graphics and layout concepts. Coupled with the software tools to apply these concepts, learners will create digital assets and combine them into a coherent design for different digital platforms.   Learners are expected to demonstrate their skills and knowledge in a capstone project as part of this course.  This course is for learners who wish to build a new career in visual and graphic design. This course is also useful for professionals in marketing roles who need to develop capabilities to create digital collaterals for below-the-line or social media projects.
course_learning_outcomes: This course is designed for learners to gain the skills required to design for various types of digital platforms, and projects incorporating design concepts, artwork, and layouts to meet the communication objectives of a creative brief.
course_entry_req:
1. Computer competency and literacy
2. Familarity with the use of images and design for presentations or marketing is an advantage

course_title: Developing Application with Large Language Model
course_title_cleaned: Developing Application with Large Language Model
course_objective: This intensive, hands-on workshop will provide a comprehensive overview of developing applications with large language models (LLMs). Over the course of three days, participants will learn the fundamental concepts of transformer models and how to engineer effective prompts to direct LLMs. We will explore the full lifecycle of a generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) project from ideation to deployment. Through practical sessions, attendees will gain expertise in training, evaluating and deploying LLMs for custom use cases. The workshop will also cover core components of LangChain and equip participants with the skills to set up the environment, manage memory and embeddings, conduct Quality Assurance (QA) over documents, integrate tools and callbacks, deploy local models, utilize open-source LLMs like llama 2, and ultimately deploy LLM applications. Participants will leave equipped to build their own solutions leveraging the power of modern language processing.
course_learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, participants will be able to:
• Understand the fundamental concepts and architecture of Transformer models, which are foundational to modern language processing
• Acquire the ability to engineer effective prompts that can direct generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) models to produce specific desired outcomes
• Explore the full lifecycle of a generative AI project, encompassing stages from conceptualization to deployment
• Develop expertise in the training and evaluation of large language models (LLMs) for tailored use cases.
• Learn the essential components of LangChain
• Gain practical experience in the setup and installation of LangChain, preparing the environment for language processing tasks
• Implement and utilize memory strategies within LangChain to maintain contextual awareness across conversational interactions
• Use document loaders and transformers to handle and convert textual data into a format suitable for processing by LLMs
• Master the creation of text embeddings, their management in vector databases, and their role in information retrieval
• Conduct hands-on Question & Answer sessions over documents using LLMs and assess the applications’ performance for accuracy and relevance
• Dive into the advanced functionalities of LangChain, learning to integrate agents, tools, callbacks, logging, and providers for robust application development
• Learn to integrate LangChain with local LLMs for building and deploying language models directly on personal or on-premise hardware
• Explore the utilization of open-source LLMs like llama 2 within LangChain, understanding the benefits and limitations of open-source models in the development of language applications
• Execute the deployment of LLM applications
course_entry_req:
Proficiency in English &
Preferred:
- Basic Python programming
- Experience working with JSON formats
- Comfort using command line interfaces
- Understanding of REST APIs
full_course_desc:

REPUBLIC POLYTECHNIC

• Develop expertise in the training and evaluation of large language models (LLMs) for tailored use cases.
• Learn the essential components of LangChain
• Gain practical experience in the setup and installation of LangChain, preparing the environment for language processing tasks
• Implement and utilize memory strategies within LangChain to maintain contextual awareness across conversational interactions
• Use document loaders and transformers to handle and convert textual data into a format suitable for processing by LLMs
• Master the creation of text embeddings, their management in vector databases, and their role in information retrieval
• Conduct hands-on Question & Answer sessions over documents using LLMs and assess the applications’ performance for accuracy and relevance
• Dive into the advanced functionalities of LangChain, learning to integrate agents, tools, callbacks, logging, and providers for robust application development
• Learn to integrate LangChain with local LLMs for building and deploying language models directly on personal or on-premise hardware
• Explore the utilization of open-source LLMs like llama 2 within LangChain, understanding the benefits and limitations of open-source models in the development of language applications
• Execute the deployment of LLM applications

# course entry req
Proficiency in English &
Preferred:
- Basic Python programming
- Experience working with JSON formats
- Comfort using command line interfaces
- Understanding of REST APIs

course_learning_outcomes: Explore the intricacies of ISO 22301 and master the design, implementation, and improvement of Business Continuity Management Systems (BCMS). This course offers deep insights into risk assessment, disaster management, and best practices for establishing resilient business continuity plans.

course_title: Branded Customer Experience Strategy and Design
course_title_cleaned: Branded Customer Experience Strategy and Design
course_objective: In today's business environment, customer experience (CX) has overtaken price and product to gain competitive advantage. According to a recent Global Customer Experience Benchmarking Report, 90.9% of organizations agree that CX is a primary differentiator.    With increasing customer expectations brought about by limitless product choices, organizations must recognize that failure to stand out will be detrimental to business survival. The end-to-end experience delivery – starting from product search to the purchase experience and all the way to the customers’ use of the product or service – must be seamlessly exceptional yet true to the uniqueness of the organization’s values and brand promise.
course_learning_outcomes:
Participants will be introduced to two digital tools, Persona Maps and Customer Journey Maps, that are used to document customer insights and the current customer experience delivery in their organisation.  The process of mapping current customer experiences is an integral step in understanding customer expectations and whether the organisation’s service delivery meets these expectations. By doing so, pain points in crucial moments of truth are highlighted. 

Armed with these powerful determinants of how to influence customer behavior and loyalty towards the brand, participants will be ready to design a Branded CX model unique to their own organization’s brand promise. They will be guided by experienced Nanyang Polytechnic's domain specialists who provide consultancy in implementing the course concepts into fruition.
course_entry_req: Supervisors and managers who have involvement in service quality, operations, marketing, customer experience or customer service, as part of their work role.
full_course_desc:
# course provider
NANYANG POLYTECHNIC

# course title
Branded Customer Experience Strategy and Design

# course url
/content/portal/en/training-exchange/course-directory/course-detail.html?courseReferenceNumber=TGS-2024041212

# course duration
3-5 days

# full course fee
$2,250.00

# subsidised course fee
$675.00

# course number of hours
35.00 hours

# course language
English

# course objective
In today's business environment, customer experience (CX) has overtaken price and product to gain competitive advantage. According to a recent Global Customer Experience Benchmarking Report, 90.9% of organizations agree that CX is a primary differentiator.    With increasing customer expectations brought about by limitless product choices, organizations must recognize that failure to stand out will be detrimental to business survival. The end-to-end experience delivery – starting from product search to the purchase experience and all the way to the customers’ use of the product or service – must be seamlessly exceptional yet true to the uniqueness of the organization’s values and brand promise.

# course learning outcomes
Participants will be introduced to two digital tools, Persona Maps and Customer Journey Maps, that are used to document customer insights and the current customer experience delivery in their organisation.  The process of mapping current customer experiences is an integral step in understanding customer expectations and whether the organisation’s service delivery meets these expectations. By doing so, pain points in crucial moments of truth are highlighted. 

Armed with these powerful determinants of how to influence customer behavior and loyalty towards the brand, participants will be ready to design a Branded CX model unique to their own organization’s brand promise. They will be guided by experienced Nanyang Polytechnic's domain specialists who provide consultancy in implementing the course concepts into fruition.


# course entry req
Supervisors and managers who have involvement in service quality, operations, marketing, customer experience or customer service, as part of their work role.

course_title: ​​(Micro-Credential) Human Resource (HR) Innovation – Data Presentation and Organisational Diagnosis in Design Thinking​ (Classroom and Synchronous e-learning)
course_title_cleaned: ​​(Micro-Credential) Human Resource (HR) Innovation – Data Presentation and Organisational Diagnosis in Design Thinking​ (Classroom and Synchronous e-learning)
course_objective: This micro-credential course is designed to equip participants with the working knowledge and skills in framing or reframing issues or challenges through Design Thinking. Participants will apply design thinking methodologies to define Human Resource (HR) problems and generate new ideas and communicate the distilled HR-related insights for design ideas.
course_learning_outcomes:
​This Micro-Credential in Human Resource (HR) Innovation – Data Presentation and Organisational Diagnosis in Design Thinking is a collaborative endeavour brought to you by Singapore Polytechnic, School of Business in partnership with the Institute for Human Resource Professionals (IHRP). Upon successful completion, participants can apply for an IHRP Skills Badge, underscoring their expertise and dedication to advancing the HR field.

This micro-credential is designed for HR professionals seeking to enhance their analytical and problem-solving competencies – through the distillation of HR insights, and the ability to reframe HR challenges in human-centric design. Whether you are a HR executive or manager, this program equips you with the skills necessary to enhance your problem-solving capabilities for strategic advantage. 

This is a 5-week part-time course with lessons conducted in a blended learning mode, including in-class teaching and synchronised online lessons (in the evening), and face-to-face assessment.
course_entry_req: ​​Applicants must have at least 1 year of working experience in the area of human resources and have prior knowledge on HR data collection and preparation in Design Thinking.​

course_title: ASEAN Economic Community Law and Policy
course_title_cleaned: ASEAN Economic Community Law and Policy
course_objective: At the end of the course, participants would be able to:   1. Describe and explain various regional initiatives to increase the integration of ASEAN, and to generate norms and institutions. This especially for ASEAN Economic Community and ASEAN-led free trade agreements as well as for key political processes in the region; 2. Develop a critical appreciation of the development of the ASEAN Economic Community with an understanding of its present rules and approaches, its strengths and present limits;  3. Describe and explain differences (and similarities) in approaches taken by the global community and the European Union in approaching freer trade and economic integration; and 4. Develop an awareness of emerging trends in the global and regional economy and the potential future needs for the ASEAN Economic Community.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law. 

ASEAN leaders agreed to create a single market – the ASEAN Economic Community – by 2015. Due to sovereignty concerns, ASEAN leaders did not create a single supranational authority to regulate this market. This course examines how ASEAN member states and institutions are filling in the vacuum through  formal and informal means. Participants will understand how regional policymaking affects domestic laws and policies within ASEAN.
course_entry_req: A good Bachelor's or Juris Doctor degree in Law

course_title: Banking Law
course_title_cleaned: Banking Law
course_objective: At the end of the course, participants will be able to:  1. Discuss the rationale of bank regulation, the challenges facing regulators, the key regulatory tools used by regulators, and their implementation in Singapore; 2. Evaluate and critique the various principles and rules governing the bank-customer relationship;  3. Evaluate and critique the various principles governing payment and the main payment mechanisms offered by banks; and 4. Apply relevant principles and rules to factual scenarios involving banks and predict the outcome of disputes.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law. 

This course is designed to familiarise the student with the key principles relating to the modern law of banking. Four main areas will be covered: the law of negotiable instruments, the law of payment systems, the banker customer relationship and bank regulation. Participants who wish to obtain a basic knowledge of banking law will benefit from this course. It is also recommended that those who wish to specialize in banking law take this course as a foundational course, prior to studying the more advanced banking courses.

course_title: IT Law I
course_title_cleaned: IT Law I
course_objective: This course aims to enable participants to:   1. Analyze the legal and policy issues surrounding information technology and Internet use, including electronic commerce, cybercrimes, electronic evidence, privacy, and data protection; 2. Evaluate the sociological, political, commercial, and technical factors influencing IT law and policy, and assess their impact on legal regulations and policy development; 3. Critically assess the legal rules and policy ramifications related to IT law, and identify gaps or areas for improvement in current regulations; and  4. Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the intersection between law, technology, and policy.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Intellectual Property & Technology Law.

This course will examine the legal and policy issues relating to information technology and the use of the Internet. Issues to be examined include the conduct of electronic commerce, cybercrimes, electronic evidence, privacy and data protection. (This course will not cover the intellectual property issues, which are addressed instead in 'IT Law: IP Issues'.) Participants who are interested in the interface between law, technology and policy will learn to examine the sociological, political, commercial and technical background behind these rules, evaluate the legal rules and policy ramifications of these rules, and formulate new rules and policies to address these problems.

course_title: International Commercial Litigation
course_title_cleaned: International Commercial Litigation
course_objective: At the end of the course, participants will be able to:  1. Understand and apply key jurisdictional techniques relevant to international commercial litigation, including in personam jurisdiction, forum non conveniens, and interim protective measures; 2. Analyze the principles and procedures for the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments in the context of international commercial disputes; 3. Evaluate the role of public policy considerations in international commercial litigation and its impact on the enforcement of foreign judgments and dispute resolution; and 4. Examine choice of law issues in international commercial contracts and understand their significance in cross-border transactions and dispute resolution, with a focus on Singapore law based on common law principles.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law.

Globalisation has made it more important for lawyers to be knowledgeable about the international aspects of litigation. This course focuses on the jurisdictional techniques most relevant to international commercial litigation: in personam jurisdiction, forum non conveniens, interim protective measures, recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments, public policy, and an outline of choice of law issues for commercial contracts. The course, taught from the perspective of Singapore law, based largely on the common law, is designed to give an insight into the world of international litigation. These skills are relevant to not only litigation lawyers, but also lawyers planning international transactions.
course_entry_req: A good Bachelor's or Juris Doctor degree in Law

course_title: International Investment Law and Arbitration
course_title_cleaned: International Investment Law and Arbitration
course_objective: At the end of the course, participants would be able to:  1. Acquire a firm grasp of international investment law and be able to apply it to a variety of hypothetical scenarios; 2. Explain the significance of arbitral awards as a source of international law vis-à-vis other sources of international law; 3. Critically evaluate the findings of arbitral tribunals and situate these findings within the broader corpus of international law; 4. Demonstrate familiarity with the content of customary and treaty protection for foreign investment; and 5. Appreciate the controversies and debates that both enrich and emasculate international investment law.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law and International Arbitration & Dispute Resolution.

The settlement of disputes arising from foreign direct investment attracts global interest and attention. Foreign investors often arbitrate their disputes with host States via an arbitration clause contained in a contract. Additionally, investment treaties also empower foreign investors to bring claims in arbitration against host State. The distinct body of law that grew into international investment law, has become one of the most prominent and rapidly evolving branches of international law. The aim of this course is to study the key developments that have taken place in the area. It deals with questions of applicable law, jurisdiction, substantive obligations, as well as award challenge and enforcement, in both investment contract arbitration and investment treaty arbitration.
course_entry_req: A good Bachelor's or Juris Doctor degree in Law
full_course_desc:
# course provider
NATIONAL UNIVERSITY OF SINGAPORE

# course title
International Investment Law and Arbitration

# course url
/content/portal/en/training-exchange/course-directory/course-detail.html?courseReferenceNumber=TGS-2024046462

# course duration
3-5 days

# course mode of training
Full Time and Part Time

# full course fee
$5,400.00

# course number of hours
27.00 hours

# course language
English

# course objective
At the end of the course, participants would be able to:  1. Acquire a firm grasp of international investment law and be able to apply it to a variety of hypothetical scenarios; 2. Explain the significance of arbitral awards as a source of international law vis-à-vis other sources of international law; 3. Critically evaluate the findings of arbitral tribunals and situate these findings within the broader corpus of international law; 4. Demonstrate familiarity with the content of customary and treaty protection for foreign investment; and 5. Appreciate the controversies and debates that both enrich and emasculate international investment law.

# course learning outcomes
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law and International Arbitration & Dispute Resolution.

The settlement of disputes arising from foreign direct investment attracts global interest and attention. Foreign investors often arbitrate their disputes with host States via an arbitration clause contained in a contract. Additionally, investment treaties also empower foreign investors to bring claims in arbitration against host State. The distinct body of law that grew into international investment law, has become one of the most prominent and rapidly evolving branches of international law. The aim of this course is to study the key developments that have taken place in the area. It deals with questions of applicable law, jurisdiction, substantive obligations, as well as award challenge and enforcement, in both investment contract arbitration and investment treaty arbitration. 

# course entry req
A good Bachelor's or Juris Doctor degree in Law

course_title: International and Comparative Oil and Gas Law
course_title_cleaned: International and Comparative Oil and Gas Law
course_objective: At the end of this course, paticipants would:  1. Examine and analyze the principles and rules governing the exploration, development, and production of oil and gas, with a focus on upstream operations; 2. Evaluate different legal arrangements between states and international oil companies, including modern concessions, production-sharing agreements, joint ventures, service contracts, and hybrid contracts, to understand their implications and applications; 3. Assess the agreements regulating relationships between companies engaged in upstream petroleum operations, such as joint operating agreements and unitization agreements, and their role in facilitating cooperation and resource optimization; and 5. Investigate and analyze key issues in international and comparative oil and gas law, including dispute settlement mechanisms, expropriation, contract stability, and the relevant international institutional and legal frameworks that govern the industry.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law.

The course explores principles and rules relating to the exploration for, development and production of oil and gas (upstream operations). The main focus of the course is on the examination of different arrangements governing the legal relationship between states and international oil companies, such as modern concessions, production sharing agreements, joint ventures, service and hybrid contracts. The agreements governing the relationships between companies involved in upstream petroleum operations (joint operating and unitisation agreements) will also be examined. The course will further explore the issues of dispute settlement, expropriation, stability of contracts and a relevant international institutional and legal framework.

course_title: Japanese Corporate Law and Governance
course_title_cleaned: Japanese Corporate Law and Governance
course_objective: At the end of the course, participants would be able to:  1. Understand the main principles governing business associations in Japan, with a focus on the legal forms available for foreign and domestic businesses operating in the country; 2. Analyze the duties, liabilities, and responsibilities of directors and officers under Japanese corporate law, and evaluate their impact on corporate governance and decision-making; 3. Examine shareholder and bondholder rights and remedies within the context of Japanese corporate law, and understand their role in protecting investor interests and ensuring corporate accountability; and 4. Evaluate the interaction between Japan's corporate law and its unique post-war system of corporate governance, and understand how these elements collectively shape the operational landscape for businesses in Japan.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law.

This course examines the main principles governing business associations in Japan, with an emphasis on business law issues affecting foreign companies. It also provides a detailed analysis of Japan's post-war corporate governance system, which is essential for understanding how Japanese business law operates in practice. The major topics covered include: legal forms for foreign and domestic businesses; duties and liabilities of directors and officers; shareholder and bondholder rights and remedies; corporate dissolution and insolvency; and, the interaction between Japan's corporate law and its unique post-war system of corporate governance.
course_entry_req: A good Bachelor's or Juris Doctor degree in Law

course_title: Principles of Financial Regulation
course_title_cleaned: Principles of Financial Regulation
course_objective: This course aims to convey to its participants the following learning outcomes:    1. to familiarize participants with the concept of banks and the particular risks involved in the banking business; 2. to familiarize participants with the goals of financial regulation and the institutions that establish the regulatory rules that govern banks; and 3. to familiarize participants with the challenges for regulators and supervisors resulting from risks to financial stability.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course is offered under the Faculty of Law's Graduate Coursework Programmes in Corporate & Financial Services Law.

Principles of financial regulation familiarises participants with the concepts underlying the rules that legitimise providers of financial services and draw limits to their activities. Participants will learn about the roles of financial markets, financial intermediaries and financial products. They are taught about the risks that result from activities in financial markets for relevant stakeholder groups and financial stability. Since banks are the most prominent providers of financial services and rely on extremely risky business models, their activities and regulation form a core part of the course. In addition, the course covers the principles of financial markets regulation.

course_title: Driving Sustainable Business Innovation Using Design Thinking (Classroom and Asynchronous e-learning)
course_title_cleaned: Driving Sustainable Business Innovation Using Design Thinking (Classroom and Asynchronous e-learning)
course_objective: The participant-centred programme focuses on supporting individuals in their sustainability efforts through raising awareness of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) requirements by utilising a Design Thinking and Humanity-Centred Innovation (HCI) step by step approach. Through the framework of people (stakeholders who are impacted, directly or indirectly), products (innovative products & services) and profits (economic impact & benefits) participants will gain awareness through a customised plan for adopting actionable sustainable strategies. The program also helps participants evaluate their organisation's current sustainability standing, offering valuable insights and strategies towards Sustainable Business Innovation and growth.
course_learning_outcomes: The course will provide participants with the essential knowledge, awareness, relevance and responsibilities of corporate sustainability. It will then identify gaps and how design thinking can be used as a framework in the transformation process.

course_title: Master of Science (Biodiversity Conservation and Nature-Based Climate Solutions) (BCNCS)
course_title_cleaned: Master of Science (Biodiversity Conservation and Nature-Based Climate Solutions) (BCNCS)
course_objective: The Southeast Asia region is experiencing unprecedented economic growth that is closely linked to the exploitation of natural biodiversity resources. However, responsible management of natural resources is crucial to sustainable long-term development, given the severity of climate change and the increasingly difficult challenge of discovering climate change solutions.  Master of Science in Biodiversity Conservation and Nature-based Climate Solutions programme is designed for graduates with a Bachelor’s degree who would like to learn more about and/or enhance their knowledge in biodiversity, and will equip students with key skills related to conservation efforts, environmental sustainability and climate change solutions.
course_learning_outcomes:
The MSc in Biodiversity Conservation and Nature-based Climate Solutions is a 40 units programme. The programme can be completed full-time over one year (two semesters + special semesters) or part-time over two years (four semesters) with a maximum candidature of two years for full-time students and four years for part-time students.

Students need to complete courses comprising two essential core courses (8 units) and elective courses amounting up to 20 units, and either one research project or internship course (12 units).

The course is divided into four domains, namely In-demand Digital Tools, Automation, Data Analytics, and Cybersecurity risks. Each domain is designed to provide participants with hands-on experience in the latest digital tools and techniques and equip them with the skills needed to thrive in today's digital world.
course_learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, participants will be able to achieve the following contextualized for the Food Services sector (eg. case studies and applications):
•	Experience the use of latest in-demand digital tools, for example Metaverse, and Augmented Reality, Generative AI (eg. ChatGPT) for usages like digital marketing.
•	Apply automation (hardware and software) techniques relevant to Food Services to reduce manual intervention in their daily work, with hardware (eg. robotics, IoT, etc) and software (eg. Power Automate) experiences.
•	Apply data analytics to build trend analysis for daily work monitoring eg. Sales, consumer behaviour) and data storytelling.
•	Experience and mitigate cybersecurity risks which will aid in exercising caution for cyberattacks happening daily in the workplace.

course_title: Business Idea Validation
course_title_cleaned: Business Idea Validation
course_objective: While many may agree on the importance of testing a business idea with users before building a product, many may not be aware of how to avoid common pitfalls when running these experiments.
course_learning_outcomes:
In this workshop, participants will use The Validation Board, a tool based on Eric Ries�s Lean Start-up methodology, to test remaining assumptions for your (start-up) idea, product or service. While generating a new business idea may be difficult, the greater challenge is to ensure adequate demand for the product. Testing business cases is about getting out of your comfort zone, testing assumptions, gaining insights from the testing, and designing a better/improved value proposition; again and again.

Building a start-up is not simply about building an execution plan for a business model that the entrepreneur thinks will work, but rather, a search for the actual business model itself.

course_title: Machine Vision and Pattern Recognition in Advanced Manufacturing
course_title_cleaned: Machine Vision and Pattern Recognition in Advanced Manufacturing
course_objective: This subject covers in detail the application of machine vision and pattern recognition technologies in advanced manufacturing. It provides the essential knowledge of the key components, their functions and the image processing technologies used in machine vision systems. In addition, an overview of the techniques in image analysis and the derivation of useful hidden patterns in the images are introduced. It includes the selection, development and application of suitable pattern recognition techniques to solve a given problem. These skills and knowledge could be readily applied to machine vision systems in a smart manufacturing facility.

course_title: Class A Powered Lift Unmanned Aircraft Pilot License (UAPL) Refresher Training with Assessment (Up to 25kg)
course_title_cleaned: Class A Powered Lift Unmanned Aircraft Pilot License (UAPL) Refresher Training with Assessment (Up to 25kg)
course_objective: By the end of the course, you will be able to operate a Powered-Lift Unmanned Aircraft (UA) of up to 25kg competently. You will also be able to demonstrate a strong understanding in the following areas: 1. Operating a Powered-Lift UA system 	• Pre-flight and post-flight checks of the UA, with reference to the Original Equipment Manufacturer documents and training manuals	 	• Take-Off, Precision Hovering and Precision Landing	 	• Transition From Hover To Forward Flight 	• Transition From Forward Flight To Hover	 	• Straight And Level Circuit In Forward Flight 	• Figure Of ‘8’ In Forward Flight
course_learning_outcomes:
Republic Polytechnic’s Unmanned Aircraft Pilot License (UAPL) practical course is recommended for Class A (Powered Lift) UAPL applicants who aims to renew their category Powered Lift UA systems weighing up to 25kg take-off weight. The purpose of this course is to provide applicants with practical knowledge and competency to pass a compulsory practical assessment prior to a UAPL renewal with Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS).
This 1 day course will provide basic and advance flight operations for the following types of powered lift systems:
	1) Powered Lift system less than 25kg Take-Off Weight (TOW)

A practical assessment will be conducted by CAAS Authorised Flight Examiners (AFE) at the end of this course. With their CAAS UAPL practical assessment results, applicants will be able to renew their respective Class A – Powered Lift UAPL (Limited to 25kg) with CAAS upon successful completion of the practical assessment.
Renew your 25kg Powered-Lift UAPL with us now!
course_entry_req:
16yrs old and above. 
Existing Class A Powered-Lift (up to 25kg) UAPL holder

course_title: Injury Prevention and Exercise Rehabilitation
course_title_cleaned: Injury Prevention and Exercise Rehabilitation
course_objective: The purpose of this module is to provide the student with a basic understanding of the nature of injuries in sport and in the workplace, including: causal factors, assessment, treatment, management and rehabilitation. This module will enable the student to develop injury prevention measures. The module aims to provide students with the knowledge and skills to recognise potential causes of injury and ability to devise and implement strategies to reduce risk of injury. Students will also be taught how to facilitate the recovery of function, return to physical activity or high performance using evidence-based therapeutic and exercise interventions.
course_learning_outcomes: "This Module is part of the Modular Certificate in Applied Sport Science.

course_title: Deep Learning Optimisation Techniques
course_title_cleaned: Deep Learning Optimisation Techniques
course_objective: Deep learning neural networks are generally easy to define and fit, however, they are still hard to configure for optimum performance.  There are no hard and fast rules to optimise a network for a given problem and we cannot analytically calculate the optimal model type or model configuration for a given dataset.  In this course, participants will work through techniques that improve model learning in response to a training dataset, reduced overfitting and improve prediction.   We recommend participants completed Deep Learning with Python before signing up for this course. Lesson 1:  Framework for deep learning optimization Lesson 2:  Techniques for optimising learning  Lesson 3: Techniques for optimizing generalisation  Lesson 4:  Techniques for improving prediction
course_learning_outcomes:
Deep learning neural networks are generally easy to define and fit, however, they are still hard to configure for optimum performance.  There are no hard and fast rules to optimise a network for a given problem and we cannot analytically calculate the optimal model type or model configuration for a given dataset.  In this course, participants will work through techniques that improve model learning in response to a training dataset, reduced overfitting and improve prediction.
 
We recommend participants completed Deep Learning with Python before signing up for this course.
Lesson 1:  Framework for deep learning optimization
Lesson 2:  Techniques for optimising learning 
Lesson 3: Techniques for optimizing generalisation 
Lesson 4:  Techniques for improving prediction

course_title: Applied Genomics & Proteomics - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Molecular & Microbiological Analyses (ADMP1)
course_title_cleaned: Applied Genomics & Proteomics - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Molecular & Microbiological Analyses (ADMP1)
course_objective: This module provides an insight into the fields of genomics and proteomics. Students will study the functions of genes and their interaction within a genome, the importance of the human genome project in the discovery of new drugs, gene therapy, biological sequence analysis using bioinformatics, genetically modified organisms, protein expression, structure and functions of proteins, methods of purification and analyses of proteins.
course_learning_outcomes: In the Applied Genomics & Proteomics (AGP) module, students will learn about the functions and interactions of genes within a genome, including insights into the Human Genome Project’s impact on drug discovery and gene therapy. They will also explore bioinformatics for biological sequence analysis, genetically modified organisms, protein expression, structure and function of proteins, and methods for protein purification and analysis. This knowledge prepares students for advanced roles in biotechnology and pharmaceutical research.
course_entry_req:
• A Diploma / Degree in technical disciplines such as Science, Engineering or Information Technology, or
• A Diploma or Degree in a non-engineering / non-technology disciplines AND a Credit or minimum grade of C6 in GCE "O" level Science Subject.

# course mode of training
Part Time

# full course fee
$1,198.80

# subsidised course fee
$156.35

# course number of hours
36.00 hours

# course language
English

# course objective
This module provides an insight into the fields of genomics and proteomics. Students will study the functions of genes and their interaction within a genome, the importance of the human genome project in the discovery of new drugs, gene therapy, biological sequence analysis using bioinformatics, genetically modified organisms, protein expression, structure and functions of proteins, methods of purification and analyses of proteins.

# course learning outcomes
In the Applied Genomics & Proteomics (AGP) module, students will learn about the functions and interactions of genes within a genome, including insights into the Human Genome Project’s impact on drug discovery and gene therapy. They will also explore bioinformatics for biological sequence analysis, genetically modified organisms, protein expression, structure and function of proteins, and methods for protein purification and analysis. This knowledge prepares students for advanced roles in biotechnology and pharmaceutical research.

# course entry req
• A Diploma / Degree in technical disciplines such as Science, Engineering or Information Technology, or
• A Diploma or Degree in a non-engineering / non-technology disciplines AND a Credit or minimum grade of C6 in GCE "O" level Science Subject.

course_title: WSQ CRM-Customer service (SF) (Synchronous and Asynchronous E-Learning)
course_title_cleaned: WSQ CRM-Customer service (SF) (Synchronous and Asynchronous E-Learning)
course_objective: At the end of the course, learners attaining the following Learning Outcomes is the objective of this course. Knowledge •	Define the basics of customer service management and how it relates to customer support. •	Explain the importance of managing customer support requests promptly and efficiently. •	Identify the key features of CRM Customer Service and how they can be utilized to improve customer service. •	Describe the different customer feedback collection and analysis methods available in CRM. •	Interpret the reports and understand the analytics features of CRM Customer Service.  Skills  •	Create and manage customer service tickets using CRM to ensure the timely resolution of customer issues. •	Utilise CRM Customer Service tools to manage customer support requests and provide exceptional customer service. •	Track customer feedback to identify areas for improvement and make data-driven decisions. •	Analyze customer service performance using CRM's reporting and analytics features to identify trends and areas for improvement. •	Utilise CRM's reporting and analytics features to make data-driven decisions and optimise customer service processes.
course_learning_outcomes:
The CRM Customer Service Module is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the learners for the capabilities for managing customer interactions and support. This course covers the fundamentals of customer service management, ticket creation and management, customer feedback collection and analysis, and reporting.
Throughout this course, learners will learn how to use CRM Customer Service tools to manage customer support requests and provide exceptional customer service. Learners will also learn how to create and manage customer interaction, track customer feedback, and analyze customer service performance using the platform's built-in tools.
In this module, learners will learn how the CRM platform can help improve an organization’s customer support and service management processes. This module will give the learners practical skills and knowledge to manage customer interactions and feedback effectively.
By the end of this module, learners will be able to use CRM Customer Service tools proficiently, ensuring efficient customer service and effectively tracking and analyzing customer service performance through the platform's reporting and analytics tools.
course_entry_req:
Academic Qualification - Minimum one credit in N level 
English Proficiency - Minimum  IELTS 5.5 or its equivalent

course_provider: EDUPEDIA LANGUAGE AND TRAINING PTE LTD
course_title: Conversational Vietnamese in Beginner Level
course_title_cleaned: Conversational Vietnamese in Beginner Level
course_objective: Course Objectives:  1. The course is designed to teach students the basics/beginner of Vietnamese Language and provides a thorough introduction to Vietnamese.  2. The presentation of a new language will be gradual, methodical, and clearly structured, giving learners a clear sense of progression.   3. Students will be introduced and identified the 6 different tones and the writing system of the Vietnamese language.   4. Acquire a general understanding of the cultures of Vietnam and cross-cultural communication skills.   Course Content various topics that will be covered:  Vietnamese Pronunciation, Greetings, Numbers from 1 to 1000, Family Relation, Culture, Useful Travel Words, Common Classifiers, Jobs and Professions, Food and Drink, Directions.
course_learning_outcomes: Vietnamese is a beautiful language with nothing but advantages for those willing to learn it. Speaking Vietnamese can make one communicate and connect better in networks. And thus, feel included and part of the international community. It also helps in coming closer to new people, thus making it very beneficial to learn. Knowing the language is advantageous to fostering an understanding of the Vietnamese culture and is an advantage in doing business in the country. Relations between Singapore and Vietnam have grown from strength to strength since the two countries established bilateral diplomatic relations. The expansion of trade and business contacts between Singapore and Vietnam over the years has been tremendously increasing over the years.

course_title_cleaned: Regenerative Design (PDC 2 in Specialist Diploma in Sustainable Built Environment)

Comprehend the systems approach to appreciate the role of design in integrating and restoring the natural ecosystem as an integral part of the built environment; 2.	Acquire knowledge and skillsets to implement sustainable considerations in the design and operation of green buildings in alignment with prevailing Green Mark criteria;  3.	Value waste reduction through recycling, reuse, recovery, and life cycle analysis and develop an understanding of the properties and performance attributes of alternative, eco-friendly building materials;
course_learning_outcomes: The Specialist Diploma in Sustainable Built Environment is an interdisciplinary programme that aims to equip students with the necessary knowledge, skills, and attributes to support the implementation of sustainability strategies and solutions for the design of the built environment.
course_entry_req: The minimum entry requirement for Academic CET is a Polytechnic Diploma or an ITE Technical Diploma/Technical Engineer Diploma/Work-Learn Technical Diploma in Built Environment-related discipline. Holders of other equivalent academic qualifications will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

course_title: Dynamics & Control
course_title_cleaned: Dynamics & Control
course_objective: This is a module under the Advanced Diploma in Process Control & Instrumentation.
course_learning_outcomes: This module aims to provide a thorough understanding of the fundamentals of control engineering and applications. Topics include mathematical modelling, transient analysis, error analysis and introduction to system optimization, stability analysis, s-plane analysis, frequency response analysis and compensation techniques. Basic control actions and industrial automatic controllers as well as advanced control techniques.
course_entry_req:
Applicants must possess a relevant engineering Polytechnic Diploma in electrical, electronics, mechanical, mechatronics, control, automation, energy systems, info-com, computer or chemical from recognised institution or an equivalent qualification. Preference will be given to those with relevant working experience.

Recognition of Prior Learning
Applicants who do not meet the entry requirements may be considered for admission to the course based on evidence of at least 5 years of relevant working experience or supporting evidence of competency readiness. Suitable applicants who are shortlisted may have to go through an interview and/or entrance test. The Polytechnic reserves the right to shortlist and admit applicants.
