course_title: Bachelor of Arts (Honours)
course_title_cleaned: Bachelor of Arts (Honours)
course_objective: Good undergraduate education involves a balanced combination of depth and breadth. By the end of a degree programme, graduates should know one area well, that is, be aware of its main ideas, of the possibilities and limitations of its methodology, and of its current questions and problems. The best graduates will also be able to devise solutions and pose questions of their own in this area. Properly educated graduates should also have broad exposure to other kinds of knowledge beyond their specialisation.
course_learning_outcomes: The B.A. (Hons) degree covers everything in the BA degree plus additional depth in one of the following subject majors: Chinese Studies, Chinese Language, Economics (JDP), English Language, English Language and Linguistics, English Literature, European Studies, Geography (JDP), Global Studies, History, Japanese Studies, Malay Studies, Philosophy, Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE), Political Science (JDP), Southeast Asian Studies, South Asian Studies, Theatre Studies, and Theatre and Performance Studies.

1) are technically competent to solve complex problems in computer engineering and can adapt effectively in a fast changing environment 2) are able to critically think, analyse and make decisions that give due consideration to global issues in business, ethics, society and the environment 3) are able to communicate effectively, act with integrity, and have the inter-personal skills needed to engage in, lead, and nurture diverse teams 4) are committed to lifelong learning, resourceful and embrace global challenges and opportunities to make a positive impact in society.

course_title: Bachelor of Laws (Hons.), 3-year Graduate LL.B.
course_title_cleaned: Bachelor of Laws (Hons.), 3-year Graduate LL.B.
course_objective: To inject multidisciplinary talent into the legal profession, as the demands of the profession become more sophisticated and technical in certain areas like patent law, environmental law and computer law. This Programme is open to University graduates with a first degree. Applicants must be prepared to do the course full-time for three years.
course_learning_outcomes:
Graduate LL.B. Programme students must complete a total minimum of 120 units in three years, 88 units of which consist of the compulsory core law curriculum (CCLC). The objectives of the CCLC are: 
-to give students an understanding of the basic law courses and general principles of law that are essential for every law graduate and lawyer; 
-to provide students with training in the basic skills essential for every lawyer, including analysis, research, writing, advocacy and problem-solving; and 
-to give students an appreciation of the role of law and lawyers in their own society and in the global community that will better equip them to deal with the challenges of globalization.

In their Third Year, students choose courses from many clusters including, Asian Legal Studies, Corporate & Financial Sevices Law, Intellectual Property & Technology Law, International & Comparative Law, Maritime Law, Law & Soiety, Research and Skills.

course_title: Bachelor of Music
course_title_cleaned: Bachelor of Music
course_objective: The Bachelor of Music degree programme is designed to prepare performing and creative musical artists for a diverse range of relevant graduate or professional opportunities, both in the Asia-Pacific region and around the world. The programme aims to help students achieve musical excellence in their specialisation by developing their self-awareness, intuition, imagination and capacity for effective communication. The Conservatory offers the Bachelor of Music (Honours) degree, with majors in Performance (Piano and Orchestral Instruments), Composition, Recordings Arts and Sciences and Voice. This is a four-year full-time music degree programme focusing particularly on music performance with appropriate supporting academic studies. The Conservatory also offers the Joint Bachelor of Music Degree programme with the Peabody Institute at the Johns Hopkins University (JHU). This is the first and only international undergraduate conservatory music programme of its kind in the world.
course_learning_outcomes: The curriculum is structured around major requirements, faculty requirements, university requirements and conservatory requirements. All students in the different majors take 88MCs worth of modules under applied major studies, ensembles/class activities/ and professional development modules. About a quarter of the curriculum comes under faculty requirements,  where students take modules in theory and history modules, including Conducting. The remaining modules come from Singapore Studies, unrestricted electives and humanities modules.

course_title: Bachelor of Science (Mathematics) (Hons)
course_title_cleaned: Bachelor of Science (Mathematics) (Hons)
course_objective: Mathematics conceptualises the concrete and generalises the specific.  Its foundations are built on three main areas: algebra, analysis and geometry.  Mathematics provides a framework for the laws of physics and chemistry and a theoretical toolkit for applications in the physical and biological sciences, computer science, engineering, operations research, economic and statistical sciences and many areas of organised human knowledge. Major in Mathematics is the flagship major that any leading university of the world is obliged to offer. The mathematical training is guided by an educational philosophy that fosters logical and critical thinking, and develops capabilities to conceptualise, improvise and innovate during the process of formulating, analysing and solving problems.
course_learning_outcomes:
Students will be exposed to all important areas of mathematical knowledge including algebra, logic, number theory and combinatorics, real and complex analysis, differential equations, geometry and topology with focus on mathematical foundations and fundamental techniques. Students can look forward to reading modules such as MA2101/MA2101S Linear Algebra II, MA2108/MA2108S Mathematical Analysis I, MA2216/ST2131 Probability, MA1102R Calculus, PC2130 Quantum Mechanics I, PC2132 Classical Mechanics, ST2132 Mathematical Statistics, PC3238 Fluid Dynamics, ST3236 Stochastic Processes I, MA3215 Three-dimensional Differential Geometry, and MA4266 Topology.
For the full list of modules and other information regarding this course, please refer to http://ww1.math.nus.edu.sg/undergrad.aspx?f=UP-MA.

course_title: Creative Communication Strategies
course_title_cleaned: Creative Communication Strategies
course_objective: Distinguish between critical and creative communication in the process of communication. Explain the elements of creativity and the creative process and recognise the roles of brainstorming and creative mindfulness in advancing communication. Apply the components of good communication to develop communication that is creative and engaging. Discuss the creative communication techniques in communications industries such as advertising, marketing, journalism, public relations and human resource management. Analyse the differences between online and traditional media and be mindful of the ethical and legal framework within which they operate within society. Write creatively using techniques such as brainstorming. Expand the scope of communication through divergent thinking. Develop effective communication skills that are effective, creative and engaging. Employ consumer-centric creative communication techniques in industries such as advertising, marketing, journalism, public relations and human resource management.
course_learning_outcomes: Creativity can be defined as “new and innovative ways of doing things” and encourages thinking “out of the box.” It avoids formality and logic and thereby engages the audience effectively. However, proper communication requires clarity and critical thinking. The requirements for creativity and communication seem to be contradictory. By communicating clearly to our audience, we may risk losing the factors that attract our audience. How to make our audience pay attention to us and make our messages memorable is a challenge to all strategic and corporate communication professionals. This course guides students through the steps of creative communication strategies. The course introduces concepts and principles from Psychology, Visual Communication and Design Arts that serve as the foundation for creative communication. Students will learn to apply strategic creativity in strategic communication professions. At the end of the course, students will be capable of addressing communication strategies and creativity in campaigns developed in the new communication environment.

At the end of the course, students will be capable of addressing communication strategies and creativity in campaigns developed in the new communication environment.

course_title: Doctor of Philosophy (industrial Design)
course_title_cleaned: Doctor of Philosophy (industrial Design)
course_objective: 3-5 years full time by research Pre-requisites: Master of Arts of Industrial Design or its international academic equivalent. The M.A. /Ph.D. (ID) is a graduate programme by research that serves to advance the study of Industrial Design. It emphasizes a holistic approach to research in design thinking and practice. Candidates undertake research across a spectrum of design issues, from design processes and methods, to design problems concerning product users.  The research methodology also focuses on interactive design, environmental and sustainability concerns. The research areas of the Industrial Design programme include design theory, practice and innovation, technology and universal design, and biomedical equipment design
course_learning_outcomes:
Students are required to take six graduate level modules plu sone seminar moudule.  This provides a graduate level foundation and prepares the student for research work. The modules offered vary year to year, please refer to the programme website for information on the modules.
Students has to take a Ph.D. qualifying examination to ensure that they are making headway in the right direction. 
The research works which forms the largest single component culminate to a thesis will be examined. Students also undergo and pass an oral examination of their research work before a panel. 

Student will work under the supervision of an academic staff member whose research interests are in the area proposed by the student.

course_title: Doctor of Philosophy in Economics
course_title_cleaned: Doctor of Philosophy in Economics
course_objective: The NUS Economics Department is widely considered a world leading Economics Department and perhaps the best in Asia in terms of research. Doctoral students get the opportunity to interact with more than 50 faculty members, whose expertise cover all the major areas of economics
course_learning_outcomes: The Department of Economics has an established reputation as one of the largest and leading departments of Economics in the Asia-Pacific region. Faculty members? research areas span a wide range of economic fields, with strength in the core areas of microeconomics, macroeconomics and econometrics, as well as in particular fields such as game theory and industrial organization, labour economics, education, financial economics, and growth theory and development with special reference to Asia. Our faculty members have recently published in top journals. Recognition of the contributions by the faculty has, inter alia, taken the form of editorships; election to membership of scholarly societies; invitations to scholarly conferences; and consultancies with international organizations and the governments of Singapore and other ASEAN countries. Because of the size and diversity of the faculty and the range of its curricular offerings, students can specialize in almost any area of interest in Economics. The Doctor of Philosophy and the Master of Social Sciences degrees are offered by the department.

course_title: Doctor of Philosophy in Southeast Asian Studies
course_title_cleaned: Doctor of Philosophy in Southeast Asian Studies
course_objective: The MA by research and PhD programmes provide postgraduate training for individuals who will contribute to knowledge production in and about Southeast Asia. Students will be taught by highly rated staff whose expertise lies in fields ranging from history, economics and political science to anthropology, cultural studies and archaeology. Our inter-disciplinary structure exposes students to the latest theoretical and methodological issues while also ensuring deep immersion in regional specificities.
course_learning_outcomes:
The PhD programme provides post-graduate training for individuals who will contribute to knowledge production in and about Southeast Asia. Candidates will be taught by highly rated staff whose expertise lies in fields ranging from history, economics and political science to anthropology, cultural studies, and archaeology. 

Our inter-disciplinary structure exposes students to the latest theoretical and methodological issues while also ensuring deep immersion in regional specificities. Graduates are prepared for academic careers and employment in research intensive professions which also expect working knowledge of Southeast Asian languages.

A candidate for the PhD programme must complete six courses as part of the coursework, which include a compulsory course, SE6770 Graduate Research Seminar. At least three courses must be at level 6000. Up to one course may be at level 4000. The remaining courses must be at level 5000 or 6000.

A candidate may, with the approval of the Head of the Department of Southeast Asian Studies, read up to two Independent Study courses. 

Other than completing the required coursework PhD candidates are also required to complete and submit a thesis for examination within the maximum period of his/her candidature.

course_title: Doctor of Philosophy in the Department of Biological Sciences
course_title_cleaned: Doctor of Philosophy in the Department of Biological Sciences
course_objective: The department of Biological Sciences offers higher degree programmes by research, on a part-time and full-time basis.  Our main objective is to produce research scientists, who have a deep and wide knowledge in biological sciences and to become a competent researcher who can conduct independent research in his or her chosen area.
course_learning_outcomes:
Students are required to take six graduate level modules.  This provides a graduate level foundation and prepares the student for research work. The modules offered vary year to year, please refer to the programme website for information on the modules.
Students has to take a Ph.D. qualifying examination to ensure that they are making headway in the right direction. 
The research works which forms the largest single component culminate to a thesis will be examined. Students also undergo and pass an oral examination of their research work before a panel. 

Student will work under the supervision of an academic staff member whose research interests are in the area proposed by the student.  
The research areas in the department of Biological Sciences are as follows;
-Developmental Biology 
-Cell and Molecular Biology 
-Ecology and Biodiversity 
-Environmental Biology 
-Structural Biology 
-Proteomics 
-Biophysics 
-Bioimaging Science

course_title: Introduction to Tamil Literary Criticism
course_title_cleaned: Introduction to Tamil Literary Criticism
course_objective: Discuss the various components in literary criticism.  Apply literary criticism to a given poem.  Demonstrate a deeper knowledge of literary concepts by which to analyze literary texts.  Identify literary concepts in literary texts.  Define the nature and aims of stylistics.  Outline a deeper appreciation of literary texts and literary discourse.
course_learning_outcomes: Since the Sangam Period, poets have debated and critiqued literature from a variety of angles and perspectives: moral stance, form, gender roles and power relations. This course examines, evaluates and interprets Tamil literature. It provides the basics of literary theory from which to appreciate and criticize the literary works of poets and writers. It equips students with the information and literary tools by which to approach and critique Tamil classical, medieval and contemporary literary writings.

course_title: Master in Public Administration
course_title_cleaned: Master in Public Administration
course_objective: The one-year full-time Master in Public Administration (MPA) programme prepares students for senior management roles in the public sector. It provides an intensive, interdisciplinary course of study for professionals who wish to work on increasingly complex issues shaping national, regional and global policies and projects. The LKYSPP’s Master in Public Administration aims to equip the future leaders of organisations as well as government institutions and agencies with necessary skills to take on the mantle of leadership in the public sector. Over the course of the programme, participants will be exposed to useful skills and knowledge used by researchers, public managers, leaders as well as policy practitioners. Applicants can look forward to developing their national and international network and boost their leadership and management capabilities.
course_learning_outcomes:
MPA students will be required to achieve 40 units and obtain at least a Grade Point Average (GPA) of minimum 3.0 to graduate. Students need to complete the following:
3 Core Courses
2 Elective Courses from the Management & Leadership Specialisation area
4 Elective Courses
Governance Study Project
course_entry_req: Minimum Entry is Bachelor's degree”

# course objective
The one-year full-time Master in Public Administration (MPA) programme prepares students for senior management roles in the public sector. It provides an intensive, interdisciplinary course of study for professionals who wish to work on increasingly complex issues shaping national, regional and global policies and projects. The LKYSPP’s Master in Public Administration aims to equip the future leaders of organisations as well as government institutions and agencies with necessary skills to take on the mantle of leadership in the public sector. Over the course of the programme, participants will be exposed to useful skills and knowledge used by researchers, public managers, leaders as well as policy practitioners. Applicants can look forward to developing their national and international network and boost their leadership and management capabilities.

# course learning outcomes
MPA students will be required to achieve 40 units and obtain at least a Grade Point Average (GPA) of minimum 3.0 to graduate. Students need to complete the following:
3 Core Courses
2 Elective Courses from the Management & Leadership Specialisation area
4 Elective Courses
Governance Study Project


# course entry req
Minimum Entry is Bachelor's degree”

course_title: RF and Microwave Design of Wireless Systems
course_title_cleaned: RF and Microwave Design of Wireless Systems
course_objective: Determine the parameters and characteristics of transmission lines. Use Smith chart/ Microwave network analysis/ Noise analysis in the design of wireless systems. Discuss the characteristics of active devices such as mixer, amplifier, oscillator and frequency synthesiser. Estimate the antenna parameters. Calculate signal frequency, load impedance, noise figure, power, signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and other parameters associated with wireless systems. Appraise the performance of various subsystems in a practical wireless receiver. Design impedance matching network/ amplifiers/ filters/ other systems meeting the given specifications.
course_learning_outcomes: This course reviews some fundamental principles of high frequency RF and microwave networks. Discussion of system parameters for various components that form building blocks for a wireless receiver system. They include amplifiers, oscillators, mixers, filter and antennas. Design approaches of all the blocks will be discussed in detail. A chapter on modulation methods allows the students to understand and characterize the wireless system from an input data stream through the transmitter, antennas and propagation channel, and the receiver. After completing the course, the students should be able to design a receiver for a wireless application system and evaluate the system performance.

Discuss the characteristics of active devices such as mixer, amplifier, oscillator and frequency synthesiser. Estimate the antenna parameters. Calculate signal frequency, load impedance, noise figure, power, signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and other parameters associated with wireless systems. Appraise the performance of various subsystems in a practical wireless receiver. Design impedance matching network/ amplifiers/ filters/ other systems meeting the given specifications.

# course learning outcomes
This course reviews some fundamental principles of high frequency RF and microwave networks. Discussion of system parameters for various components that form building blocks for a wireless receiver system. They include amplifiers, oscillators, mixers, filter and antennas. Design approaches of all the blocks will be discussed in detail. A chapter on modulation methods allows the students to understand and characterize the wireless system from an input data stream through the transmitter, antennas and propagation channel, and the receiver. After completing the course, the students should be able to design a receiver for a wireless application system and evaluate the system performance.

course_title: Semiconductor Devices
course_title_cleaned: Semiconductor Devices
course_objective: Discuss the fundamentals of semiconductor devices such as pn junction, bipolar junction transistors, field effect transistors, light emitting diodes and photovoltaic devices. Illustrate the breakdown mechanism in pn junctions and the characteristics of the different metal semiconductor contacts. Apply suitable mathematical model to study the performance of semiconductor devices. Appraise the circuit parameters for the transistor’s different operational modes. Assess the impact of change in bias voltage, temperature, size and other parameters on the functioning of semiconductor devices. Calculate bias voltage, mole fraction, size, current flow, voltage, resistance and other parameters associated with semiconductor devices.
course_learning_outcomes: This course covers the principles of operation of various semiconductor electronic and photonic devices, and their fabrication and applications. Topics include the fundamental physical principles of semiconductor/metal contacts/junctions, the use of mathematical models to describe the physical behaviour of BJTs, MOSFETs and junction FETs, and the operation and construction of optoelectronic devices (LEDs and solar cells).

Apply suitable mathematical model to study the performance of semiconductor devices. Appraise the circuit parameters for the transistor’s different operational modes. Assess the impact of change in bias voltage, temperature, size and other parameters on the functioning of semiconductor devices. Calculate bias voltage, mole fraction, size, current flow, voltage, resistance and other parameters associated with semiconductor devices.

# course learning outcomes
This course covers the principles of operation of various semiconductor electronic and photonic devices, and their fabrication and applications. Topics include the fundamental physical principles of semiconductor/metal contacts/junctions, the use of mathematical models to describe the physical behaviour of BJTs, MOSFETs and junction FETs, and the operation and construction of optoelectronic devices (LEDs and solar cells).

course_title: Workforce Planning
course_title_cleaned: Workforce Planning
course_objective: Illustrate the frameworks and theories in workforce planning. Recommend workforce planning strategies to support organisation strategy. Judge the impact of the economic, labor and political environment on workforce planning. Examine strategic job analysis as a prelude to forecasting and planning for staffing requirements, applying basic statistical tools. Apply basic statistical tools in measuring the effectiveness of recruitment and selection processes. Illustrate an organisation’s management of its workforce flow into, through and out of the organisation.
course_learning_outcomes: Workforce planning is an integral part of organizational performance and success. It provides management with a way to align the workforce with its business strategies and address current and future staffing requirements. Good planning creates direction and a foundation for allocating resources. While workforce planning is chiefly a responsibility of management, several business units within the organisation contribute towards the overall plan, including human resources.

course_title: Food Waste Disposal and Reduction Level 2
course_title_cleaned: Food Waste Disposal and Reduction Level 2
course_objective: The food and beverage (F&B) industry plays a pivotal role in managing food waste due to its significant contribution to the overall food waste in Singapore. This course is specifically designed for F&B professionals to enhance their proficiency in food waste disposal and reduction strategies, aligning with the national objectives of the Zero Waste Masterplan.  Skillmaster, a leader in F&B training, recognizes the need for heightened awareness and action in waste reduction. Committed to empowering the industry, Skillmaster provides comprehensive education in food safety and service excellence, supporting the F&B sector's contribution to national waste reduction goals.  Through the Food Waste Disposal and Reduction (Level 2) training, F&B professionals will learn to dispose of food waste according to Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).
course_learning_outcomes:
•	Able to dispose food waste correctly in accordance with standard operating procedures (SOPs)
•	Able to identify and implement cross-contamination prevention, proper effluent discharge, and health and safety compliance.
•	Able to identify causes of food spoilage and wastage and apply preventive measures to minimize food spoilage and waste.
•	Able to operate food waste processing equipment effectively, considering recycling and eco-friendly practices.
•	Able to categorise food preparation states effectively
course_entry_req:
•	Able to read, write and speak in English (WLPN Level 3 and above).
•	Min. 21 years old. 
•	Primary school level education and above
•	Learners who do not meet the minimum entry requirements above may be considered through interviews on a case-by-case basis.

course_title: Intelligence Life Cycle (Synchronous and Asynchronous Learning)
course_title_cleaned: Intelligence Life Cycle (Synchronous and Asynchronous Learning)
course_objective: This course explores the Cyber Threat Intelligence Lifecycle, covering strategic planning, data collection, processing and exploitation, analysis and production, and dissemination. Learners will gain practical skills to effectively manage and apply this lifecycle framework in real-world scenarios.
course_learning_outcomes:
The cyber threat intelligence lifecycle constitutes an ongoing process that encompasses the gathering, analysis, and dissemination of information pertaining to potential cyber threats. It commences with the collection of data from a multitude of sources, including security logs, monitoring of the dark web, and feeds from threat intelligence sources. Subsequently, this data undergoes scrutiny and assessment to discern patterns, trends, and potential risks.
Upon the completion of the analysis, actionable intelligence is generated and shared with relevant stakeholders. This equips them with the insights needed to make informed decisions and proactively counteract cyber threats. Feedback and insights derived from the outcomes of these actions are then utilised to refine and enhance the process of collecting and analysing intelligence, thereby ensuring a continuous cycle of improvement in threat intelligence.
This course serves as a valuable resource for enhancing the skills of current information technology (IT) professionals aspiring to excel in the realms of cyber or data governance. It is particularly relevant for those operating within the banking and finance sector, as well as in other industries engaged in e-business interactions with the banking and financial sector.
course_entry_req: This course is suitable for cybersecurity analysts, information system auditors, law enforcement, security architects, system designers, and system administrator. Learners are expected to have basic knowledge in the core modules of cybersecurity, cybersecurity risk management and cryptography before taking this module.

course_title: Current Group Approaches in Social Work
course_title_cleaned: Current Group Approaches in Social Work
course_objective: "At the end of the course, students are expected to: 1. Understand what group work entails and examine current theories that inform group work practice in Singapore’s social work.  2  Plan and conduct groups with clear needs and goals with an understanding of group work processes.  3.Evaluate the group work process and content.   4. Demonstrate understanding of the use of self as a group work facilitator and begin to embark on the process in class.  5. Achieve basic competencies needed for group work as well as some elements essential in supervision of  group work.   6. Reflect and improve on the current processes they are using and evaluate how the lectures and tutorials are similar or differ from their practice modality. "
course_learning_outcomes: This module outlines the current theories and principles of group social work. The focus will be on the principles and skills of group assessment and intervention in a clinical setting. This is an experiential course where students will focus on designing and conducting a group work program for a special population. Skills in selecting an appropriate theoretical framework, planning session contents and activities, conducting and evaluating the sessions will be emphasized in the CA where students are expected to conduct group sessions and write a report on outcome and learning experiences. The students will examine group work competencies and supervision of group work.
course_entry_req: A Bachelor degree in any discipline and minimum 3 years of working experience as Social Service Practitioner

course_title: Graduate Certificate in Innovative Approaches to Adult Learning - GCIAL (f2f, sync)
course_title_cleaned: Graduate Certificate in Innovative Approaches to Adult Learning - GCIAL (f2f, sync)
course_objective: Graduates of the GCIAL will have a good understanding of major learning theories and their own beliefs and assumptions about adult learners and learning. They will be able to design and facilitate learning and assessment appropriately and relevantly for their adult learners, and draw on technology effectively to support adult learners in the classroom, work settings and online.
course_learning_outcomes:
The Graduate Certificate in Innovative Approaches to Adult Learning (GCIAL) is a 15-credit unit, 16-week programme comprising three courses focusing on understanding the practice of adult learning, designing for learning and assessment in the adult learning context, and integrating technology in learning at the workplace. 

The GCIAL is an elective certificate in the Master in Boundary-Crossing Learning and Leadership (MBX), and stackable towards that qualification. 
The GCIAL is a core certificate in the Adult Learning track of the Master programme.
course_entry_req:
Applicants are required to meet the following criteria:
1) possess at least an undergraduate degree or an equivalent qualification from a recognised institution
2) possess at least 2 years of work experience, since practice and work contexts would be the basis for the application of learning to and from the programme.
3) must be Singapore Citizen, permanent resident or a resident in Singapore.

course_title: PWM-Cleaning: Customer Management (Provide Quality Services)
course_title_cleaned: PWM-Cleaning  Customer Management (Provide Quality Services)
course_objective: This course is only for the low wage workers in the PWM-Cleaning Sector.  By the end of the class/ workshop, learners will be able to:  1)  Identify the types of triggers in the service environment that may lead to potential service challenges  2)  Provide quality customer service by addressing customers'  concerns promptly 3)  Identify and apply problem solving tools and techniques to assess customer needs  4)  Apply effective communication to identify and clarify customer needs and expectations  5)  Apply service recovery procedures to respond to service challenges  6)  Establish and promote a positive, integrated system of complaint reviews and resolution procedure
course_learning_outcomes:
Service quality is considered as an important tool for a company to differentiate itself from its competitors. It is a measure of how well the service level delivered matches customer expectations. Delivering quality service means conforming to customer expectations on a consistent basis. 

Customers who believe the service being provided is below their expectations will have a range of negative thoughts regarding the service. Changing a customer’s thoughts of the service being provided can be difficult and will require the input from company management to firstly explain the problems and secondly agree how to fix the problem. The frequency of customer contact in this industry makes good personal presentation very important.  We need to be aware that people often form an opinion about us personally, and the establishment we work for as a result of our appearance before we speak to them. They very often form their opinion based on what they see initially. As a result we must make sure we always maintain high levels of personal presentation.

Working in the cleaning industry also involves communicating with clients and other staff members on a regular basis. Every staff member will need to communicate with users, and other colleagues etc. In order to provide professional customer service the staff member must have communication skills as well as a good knowledge of the services your company provides. Providing assistance and information in a prompt manner may include a customer asking the cleaner for the location of a restroom, location of an ATM or the location of a business in the building.
course_entry_req:
•	The level of English language proficiency to be at WLPN Level 1
•	No work experience required 
•	Majority of learners come with language barriers due to low educational level. The program though conducted in English, requires our trainers to translate some of the content to Mandarin, Malay, sometimes Tamil and to different dialects to meet the special needs of learners for ease of understanding.

course_title: CHE6032N02: Risk Based Inspection
course_title_cleaned: CHE6032N02  Risk Based Inspection
course_objective: •	Control the integrity of the asset with a focus on economic value, emphasizing the financial return on such assets.  •	Improve maintenance decisions by appropriately integrating risk information into the decision-making process  •	Focus resources on the highest-risk equipment failures that can lead to system failures  •	Reduce maintenance costs by systematically determining/optimizing facility's planned maintenance activities  •	Provide an objective means to evaluate alternative inspection and test strategies •	Provide an objective means for prioritizing corrective maintenance activities •	Establish systems to collect and analyse failure cause information and failure data
course_learning_outcomes:
Most process plants based the scope and depth of their inspection plans on the rate of in-service damage and the consequence of failure, within a traditional time-based inspection programme.
Risk Based Inspection (RBI) refers to a structured, team-based assessment process with the aim of targeting inspection by considering the following two factors:
• Probability of Failure (POF): Identify the likelihood of equipment failure based on the 3 Ds – damage, deterioration, or degradation
• Consequence of Failure (COF): How the potential failure could affect the people, equipment and work environment
An RBI risk assessment should be able to identify the following:
• What damage could occur
• Where it could occur
• How quickly will the deterioration spread
• Which piece of equipment is likely to fail first
• What impact that would have

It helps to prioritize their equipment for inspection, optimize inspection methods and frequencies, and implement effective inspection program (such as repair or replacement of equipment) and risk mitigating measure commensurate with the risk contribution and equipment condition.
This training introduce the participant RBI framework and methodology to establish and implement a risk based inspection program based on API 580 principles best suited for the company objectives.
Topics
Basic concept of Risk-Based Inspection
Purpose, scope, and RBI process critical step
RBI Data and Information Collection
RBI assessment types
Deterioration mechanisms and failure modes affecting the plant equipment.
Risk-based inspection priority matrix
Risk determination, assessment, and management
Reassessments and means for updating RBI.

course_provider: SMF CENTRE FOR CORPORATE LEARNING PTE. LTD.
course_title: Manage Strategic Resources for Logistics – OPTIMIZATION
course_title_cleaned: Manage Strategic Resources for Logistics – OPTIMIZATION
course_objective: With the growing importance of effectively scaling the business and contending with higher rates of order fulfilment to deliver at the right cost using the right resources, and despite those disruptive events and fluctuating demand and supply, resource constraints, the logistic function today must be aligned with its coherent organisational business priorities to maintain its logistics resiliency. This course is to facilitate the business to: •	Formulate the logistic strategies for becoming a collaborative enterprise that is driven by the needs of future warehouse digitization and automation. This futureproof transformation necessitates different sets of practices as well as a greater need for interdisciplinary talent to drive facilitation with various stakeholders in order to make aligned logistics solution implementation and optimization with those ever-changing situations. •	Devise a monitoring and optimization plan based on time, cost, and resource indicators for various logistical activities such as warehouse distribution and fulfilment, inventory planning and control, and transportation. These indicators must be in accordance with operational policies, optimization activities, metrics chosen, business resources, and logistics strategies. They should elicit the optimization of distribution bottlenecks, changing customer expectations, and market cost trends that may have an impact on business profitability. •	Leverage on best practices from their framed operating model to preach the benefits of end-to-end, well-integrated business processes in transportation, warehouse distribution, and inventory in order to analyse and optimise information sharing and connectivity activities. This could eliminate the need for manual coordination of fragmented and silo-based logistics activities, which is becoming increasingly inefficient as a result of constant disruptions, changing regulatory requirements, and inflationary cost trends.
course_learning_outcomes: •	Successful Manufacturing Companies in today's volatile global marketplace are scrambling to diversify and seek new sources of goods and resources, as well as exporting production output in time for the market recovery.  They need that well-collaborated logistic solutions that can integrate with production to shape demand, refine inventory requirements, deliver production output toward winning strategic goals, and maintain Logistics Resilience. This allows them to operate not only in Singapore, but also to maintain their competitive performance in terms of delivering the right manufacturing outputs at the right costs in the face of all types of market fluctuations and Logistics Changes. This begins with strengthening workforce resilience and agility in dealing with Logistics Resilience - collaboratively solutioning, analysing, and optimising logistics in the manufacturing context - while taking external business influences, production constraints, and distribution bottlenecks into account. This necessitates a structured collaborative process, to entice everyone to work cross-functionally across the organization as a whole, to stay on top of all changes. That is, a periodic review and adjustment to the demand, supply, logistic resources and inventory plan, the need for that structured collaborative process which focuses on optimized use of logistical resources at what pace, with the overall business strategy, including production, finance, and demand, in order to sustain that Resilience in Logistics. That is our intention in providing our program.
course_entry_req:
Entry requirements:
•	Logistician with at least 2 years of experience interested in learning about aligning logistic resources with business priorities or
•	Early and mid-career professionals with at least 3 years of experience in any discipline who supervise the work of others, or
•	Logistics Solutions Professional, Warehouse Operations Manager, Transportation Operations Professional with more than 2 years of supervisory experience in any logistics discipline and who are in charge of reporting logistic performance to align with company strategies or 
•	Professionals with at least 3 years of working experience and a Diploma who want to work in logistics, warehouse operations, or transportation operations.
•	Aged 25 years old and above.

course_title: Data Mining for Strategic Business Analysis
course_title_cleaned: Data Mining for Strategic Business Analysis
course_objective: Upon successful completion of this course, the learner will be able to:  1. consolidate data based on defined data requirements from relevant sources of data and sampling techniques in accordance with data collection processes and tools   2. evaluate integrity of data in accordance with the data quality standards   3. identify and select appropriate techniques and tools to extract data based on the defined requirements  4. meet the required standards of data sufficiency and adequacy to perform data analysis    5. organise the collected data in preparation for the data analyses   6. conduct preliminary data analyses for review and verification
course_learning_outcomes: This course enables learners with the knowledge and abilities to collect data using appropriate techniques and business intelligence tools to extract meaningful data for preliminary analyses according to requirements
course_entry_req:
• Be at least 21 years old
• English proficiency level equivalent to Grade C6 of GCE ‘O’ Level English or Employability Skills Workforce Skills Qualifications (ES WSQ) Workplace Literacy (WPL) Level 5.
• Numeracy skills at a proficiency level equivalent to the Employability Skills Workforce Skills Qualifications (ES WSQ) Workplace Numeracy (WPN) Level 5.
• Basic Information and Communications Technology (ICT) skills.
• Basic understanding of data.

Required years of experience in relevant domain:
Learners are expected to have at least 1 year of working experience to allow them to grasp organisation’s processes and apply the knowledge gained from the course.

course_title: Trauma Support
course_title_cleaned: Trauma Support
course_objective: Individuals often experience intense reactions at the time of the incident that may lessen within one to six months. Some may have symptoms that require on-going mental health support by mental health professional in order to engage in the normal daily tasks of living. The second group are those who, without seeking mental health professional help, can continue to function daily but may still be uncomfortably affected by the past trauma or may be triggered to experience intense reactions when they hear of similar trauma.   This training is designed to equip participants with knowledge and skills to help those in the second group described above; this workshop teaches skills to help individuals who experienced trauma but do not require prolonged therapeutic counselling given by professional psychologists.  Who should attend: This workshop is designed especially for people who works with people affected by trauma. Participants need not have pyschological background. Parents who are keen to support their child affected by trauma will also find this course helpful.
course_learning_outcomes: This workshop comprises two parts: Part 1 will provide participants with an understanding of how to treat Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). (This is based on the work of Ulrich, Anke, Elbert et al, 2015). Part 2 will equip participants with hands-on skills that they can use to help individuals cope with trauma. (This is based on the work of the National Organization for Victim Assistance (NOVA), US). Important features of providing post-trauma support will be addressed and distinctions between post-trauma support and therapeutic counselling will be discussed in this part.

course_title: Principles and Practices of Early Intervention for Children with Special Needs Module 2 (Classroom & Synchronous)
course_title_cleaned: Principles and Practices of Early Intervention for Children with Special Needs Module 2 (Classroom & Synchronous)
course_objective: LO1: Perform functional needs assessments for children LO2: Identify functional needs of the child and priorities and concerns of families and caregivers in collaboration with other professionals LO3: Identify potential intervention requirements based on functional needs assessment  LO4: Formulate an Individualised Education Plan (IEP) based on relevant assessment findings and information from families, caregivers, early intervention teachers and other professionals
course_learning_outcomes:
The training objective of this module is to equip learners with the competencies to identify the functional needs of the child under supervision (CFNAL2).

Upon completion of this course, learners will be able to perform observations and functional needs assessments according to the Early Intervention principles and practices, identify functional needs of a child from transdisciplinary perspectives, identify and develop developmental intervention requirements based on holistic functional needs assessment carried out with other professionals, families and caregivers, and provide inputs for the formulation of the Individualised Education Plan (IEP)
course_entry_req:
New entrants to social services, practitioners working in Early Intervention Programmes for Infants and Children (EIPIC) Centres; Integrated Child Care Centres (ICCC); preschools, junior classes in special education schools and early intervention roles.

The learner is required to complete either one of the following:
•	Principles and Practices of Early Intervention for Children with Special Needs Module 1
•	A Holistic Approach to Early Intervention for Children with Special Needs

course_objective: In today’s healthcare setting, patients are increasingly empowered with active involvement in decisions and actions affecting their health. Hence, learners should first be introduced to patient-centred practice as an approach to care that respects the patients and involves patients to co-own their healthcare journey. One of the important skills in patient-centred practice is communication skills. Learners acquire effective communication skills to understand patients' preferences and show that they respect patients’ perspectives. This eventually helps to build trust and rapport with patients and caregivers and encourage collaboration toward the healthcare goals.
course_learning_outcomes: Learners will apply patient-centred practice as a fundamental concept of modern healthcare, as it involves giving patients the knowledge, skills, and confidence to actively participate in their own care. This can eventually lead to improved health outcomes and a more satisfying healthcare experience for patients.

course_title: 9-Day Precision Engineering Assessment & Reskilling Lab (PEARL) CNC Turning
course_title_cleaned: 9-Day Precision Engineering Assessment & Reskilling Lab (PEARL) CNC Turning
course_objective: This course covers the fundamentals of Computer Numerical Control (CNC) technologies and programming codes (G-code/M-code), gaining hands-on experience with CNC turning machines through key operations such as datum/workpiece setup, cutting tool preparation, and script execution. They will also be exposed to basic machine maintenance and essential workplace safety protocols, ensuring they are well-equipped for practical CNC machining tasks. The course creates opportunities for career development in Precision Engineering.
course_learning_outcomes: This 9-day course comprises 4 days of lab training, conducted at Nanyang Polytechnic, followed by 5 days of practical training, conducted at a company. Learners will be equipped with all the fundamentals to operate Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machines in a manufacturing shopfloor environment. This course offers a basic introduction to various machining technologies, and then deep-dives into operating CNC turning machines, covering essential machine safety and awareness aspects. The program adopts a hands-on approach, which is well appreciated by the Precision Engineering industry and well suited for mid-career workers and kinesthetic learners.
course_entry_req: No MER

course_title: NSA - The Art of Pour-Over Coffee: From Bean to Cup
course_title_cleaned: NSA - The Art of Pour-Over Coffee  From Bean to Cup
course_objective: This pour-over coffee course is perfect for individuals seeking roles in cafés, coffee shops, restaurants, hotels, or leisure operations. It equips participants with the skills to expertly select coffee beans, understand brewing techniques, and deliver high-quality coffee experiences to customers.   With knowledge of coffee varieties, roasting processes, and hands-on brewing practice, participants can enhance customer service in settings where coffee quality is paramount. This expertise is particularly valuable in the hospitality industry, enabling workers to contribute to elevated guest experiences and drive customer loyalty in environments where coffee culture plays a significant role.
course_learning_outcomes: The course offers an immersive journey into the world of pour-over coffee, providing a detailed understanding of every step, from selecting the right coffee beans to perfecting the brewing process. Participants will learn about the different varieties of coffee, how beans are harvested, processed, and roasted, and the essential grinding techniques for pour-over brewing. With hands-on brewing practice, you'll discover the importance of water quality and temperature and refine your ability to evaluate the sensory aspects of coffee, from aroma to taste. The course also explores coffee's cultural significance, offering insight into its rich heritage across the globe.
course_entry_req: Minimum Entry Requirements

course_title: Master of Science in Quantitative Finance
course_title_cleaned: Master of Science in Quantitative Finance
course_objective: The MQF curriculum is tailored to meet the needs of the financial industry in three key areas: pricing and hedging, risk analytics and management, and quantitative trading and investment.
course_learning_outcomes:
The programme duration for both SMU MQF Local track and International track is 12 months + internship. The Local track is also available in a part-time mode of study at 24 months. The same core modules and programme fees apply for both tracks.

LOCAL TRACK
You will take all courses at SMU (Singapore) and obtain an SMU MQF Degree.
This is the preferred path for those already working in Singapore or who are unable to spend four months in London on the international track. On top of being Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) and European Quality Improvement System (EQUIS) accredited, the Lee Kong Chian School of Business is also highly ranked for its research productivity, teaching effectiveness, graduate employability and international reputation.

INTERNATIONAL TRACK
You will take your Term 1 and Term 3 Courses at SMU (Singapore), and Term 2 Courses at Bayes Business School (London, UK), and graduate with a Joint MQF degree from both institutions.
course_entry_req:
Local Track
1. Bachelor's Degree
2. IELTS/TOEFL (if undergraduate degree was not taught in English)
3. GMAT/GRE/SMU Admissions Test

International Track
1. Bachelor's Degree
2. IELTS (if undergraduate degree was not completed in the Australia, UK, US)
3. GMAT/GRE/SMU Admissions Test

course_title: Career Development and Counselling
course_title_cleaned: Career Development and Counselling
course_objective: •	Develop competencies in career theories and models to be applied in various settings and across the lifespan.  •	Evaluate career assessment tools for use within the practice of career development and counselling.   •	Assist clients in developing job search skills and strategies in tackling where and how to find employment in the job market.  •	Apply counselling and coaching skills in the career planning and job-seeking processes.  •	Adhere to professional and ethical standards related to career practitioners as stipulated by international/national counselling associations
course_learning_outcomes:
This module is part of the Post-Diploma Certificate in Career Development.

The aim of this module is to provide participants with career development theories and practices to assist clients in making choices about themselves and their careers, incorporating their family needs and their styles of interaction in the most meaningful way.
course_entry_req:
Applicants should possess at least a local diploma qualification or equivalent from recognised institution.   

Applicants who do not meet the entry requirements may be considered for admission to the course based on evidence of at least 5 years of relevant working experience or supporting evidence of competency readiness. Suitable applicants who are shortlisted will have to go through an interview and/or entrance test. The Polytechnic reserves the right to shortlist and admit applicants.

course_title: Build Creative Winning Business Strategies
course_title_cleaned: Build Creative Winning Business Strategies
course_objective: Learners will be able to:  •	Validate the Problem and its causes for the Customer Segments by relevant empathy interview techniques to identify the pain points for which solutions are sought.  •	Develop creative solutions, with the possibilities of trans-disciplinary, which create values for the Customer Segments.  •	Develop winning strategies in operations, marketing, and finances of the business through experiments.
course_learning_outcomes:
In the current disruptive economy, learners are required to think critically at work, whether as a start-up entrepreneur or a corporate employee. 

Learners who have decided to be start-up entrepreneurs have to bear the financial risk in setting their businesses. Building creative winning strategies could minimise such risk and improve business viabilities in the competitive environment,

Existing businesses are facing enormous competitions which require them to maintain their resilience by constantly innovating and moving ahead with winning strategies to meet the needs of their existing and new customers.

In this module, learners develop these entrepreneurial qualities by fostering the attitudes of self-confidence and creativity.

Learners also acquire problem-solving skills by applying the Lean Business Model Canvas methodology on a problem-driven project, through which they improve their collaboration with team members of different disciplines to develop winning business strategies.

NANYANG POLYTECHNIC

course_title: Becoming Relationally Credible
course_title_cleaned: Becoming Relationally Credible
course_objective: This is a hands-on course where participants will be equipped on how to coach individuals through application of coaching techniques and by leveraging off a coaching methodology to build the team. The learner will practice how to listen deeply and ask questions with insight to better understand the real issues that challenge workplace effectiveness and serving customers and clients; and how to communicate in a productive way towards better workplace performance, including the powerful skill of giving feedback.  Program Objectives LO1: Learner will be able to define the characteristics and roles of a coach in coaching for service performance LO2: Learner will be able to develop a coaching plan for individuals to address service performance taking into consideration barriers to learning LO3: Learner will be able to use coaching techniques to provide feedback on areas of improvement and address service performance gaps LO4: Learner will be able to employ techniques to monitor progress and improvements in service performance
course_learning_outcomes:
Learning Unit 1 (LU1): Introduction to Coaching
Learning Unit 2 (LU2): Create a Coaching Plan
Learning Unit 3 (LU3): Apply Coaching Techniques at the Workplace
Learning Unit 4 (LU4) :Monitor Progress of Service Performance
course_entry_req:
For this course, learners are assumed to:
1. Have an understanding of the organisation’s vision, mission, values, processes and procedures
2. Have an understanding of the organization’s product and service offering
3. Have an understanding of the organization’s service excellence procedures and practices and be able to impart service practices to peers, juniors and subordinates
4. Have 2 years of experience in a service-related capacity
5. Be able to speak, listen and read English at a proficiency level not lower than the Employability Skills Workforce Skills Qualification (ES WSQ) Workplace Literacy (WPL) Level 4

course_title: ER Management Level 5: Develop and Evaluate Framework for Managing Conflict, Grievances and Disputes (Synchronous e-learning)
course_title_cleaned: ER Management Level 5  Develop and Evaluate Framework for Managing Conflict, Grievances and Disputes (Synchronous e-learning)
course_objective: This unit addresses the skills and knowledge to develop a framework to resolve organisational  conflict, grievances and disputes. It includes developing a conflict management framework, consulting key stakeholders and reviewing the conflict management framework to maintain or enhance positive employee relations.
course_learning_outcomes:
A competent individual must be able to successfully perform the following:
1. Develop a framework for managing conflict, grievances and disputes, taking into consideration organisation’s context and legal, ethical and socio-cultural considerations relating to conflict, grievance and dispute
resolutions
2. Consult key stakeholders to obtain buy-in on the framework and ensure alignment to organisation objectives
3. Review framework for managing conflict, grievances and disputes to maintain or enhance positive employee relations
course_entry_req:
Prospective candidates should have a minimum bachelor’s degree in any discipline and at least 2 years of HR or people management experience
OR 
Diploma holders with at least 3 years of HR or people management experience may also be accepted.

course_title: Crisis Communication and Reputation (Classroom & Asynchronous e-learning)
course_title_cleaned: Crisis Communication and Reputation (Classroom & Asynchronous e-learning)
course_objective: This course covers managing reputation, crisis, and media relations. By the end of this course, learners will be able to apply theories and best practices to: 1) Develop a proactive crisis management plan  2) Develop a reputation and thought leadership programme  3) Analyse and see the game ahead to propose programmes that would generate goodwill for the organisation and negate a crisis,  4) Track Issues and manage responses.  5) Train media spokesperson and write for executive communication during a crisis.   6) Manage the media.
course_learning_outcomes:
This course equips communication professionals with the skills to manage their organisation's reputation and rebound from crises effectively. In the critical fields of crisis communication and reputation management, learners will learn to develop and execute well-prepared plans to address issues swiftly and engage with stakeholders transparently.

This course provides learners with both theoretical insights and practical applications, placing emphasis on proactive strategies and adept handling of crises to protect and enhance an organisation's image.

Learners will explore strategic approaches to maintaining brand integrity, fostering trust, and building long-term resilience. By the end of this course, learners will be well-prepared to lead their organisations through minor setbacks or major challenges, enhancing their long-term growth and vitality with confidence and integrity.
course_entry_req: This course is suitable for learners working/ intending to work in the media and communication industry. We welcome learners who are working in different functions within a business unit to understand how to develop and work with corporate communication during a crisis.

course_title: TFIP - Building the Foundation for an Ethical Organisation (Synchronous e-Learning)
course_title_cleaned: TFIP - Building the Foundation for an Ethical Organisation (Synchronous e-Learning)
course_objective: Breach of ethical integrity has proven to be a sudden and devastating crisis that can break organisations that were once flag bearers. Ethical Compliance is a critical area that needs to be addressed through active mechanisms and infused into the organization’s DNA.   This two-days course will equip participants with a clear understanding of what ethical compliance encompasses, its unique challenges, and the mechanisms that can be adopted to manage it. Participants will also be exposed to specific business ethical compliance topics such as fraud, bribery and corruption, conflict of interest, etc. and learn how to prevent, detect, correct, and investigate such incidents.
course_learning_outcomes:
•	Strengthens your understanding on the importance of ethics in finance using a systems approach incorporating elements such as a code of conduct and standardized methods of ethics checks.
•	Learn how the structure of how financial professionals’ ethics is built on a culture of integrity.

course_title: Proactive Cybersecurity with Security Assessment and Testing
course_title_cleaned: Proactive Cybersecurity with Security Assessment and Testing
course_objective: Organisations rely on a stable and secure IT environment as the foundation for driving new digital innovations and products. New security vulnerabilities are published on a daily basis and cyber hackers are constantly looking for ways to gain access to systems and data. It is therefore critical to regularly test organisation’s cybersecurity defences. Identifying, managing, and correcting vulnerabilities in an environment that consists of multiple applications, systems, and locations is a significant challenge.  The key is to be proactive. The conduct of security assessment and testing (also known as Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing) provides the organisation with visibility of potential security weaknesses. VAPT helps to protect your business and provide the intelligence needed to efficiently allocate security resources.  In this 3-day overview of security assessment and testing, participants will gain an understanding of the most common techniques used to test systems, and the associated remediation steps.
course_learning_outcomes:
•	Strengthens your competencies in handling security vulnerabilities in an organisation’s IT environment.
•	Learn how to conduct of security assessment and testing (also known as Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing) to proivde the organisation with visibility of potential security weaknesses.
course_entry_req: Basic understanding of an organisation’s IT environment, will be helpful

course_title_cleaned: Knowing & Engaging Youth - Part of Post Diploma Certificate in Youth Development & Mentoring (SDYM)
course_objective: Participants will acquire an understanding of youth, including the common psychological and developmental issues that impact their lives, and be equipped with basic intervention and mentoring skills that would help them to manage these issues that include anger and aggression; youth sexuality; mental health; self-harm; family abuse & trauma; and addictions. Participants will also have a chance to apply what they have learned with youth and be mentored by youth practitioners.
course_learning_outcomes:
- Appreciate the broader social and cultural context of youth work in Singapore
- Explain youth’s psychological and developmental stages and be aware of unmet developmental needs which may manifest dysfunctional behaviours
-  Describe common topics which impact the lives of youth
-  Apply effective strategies, including active listening and mentoring techniques, to connect with youth more purposefully
- Apply basic intervention skills to guide and mentor youth in common youth issues
course_entry_req:

Degree in any discipline with at least 1 year relevant working experience.

Applicants who do not meet the Minimum Entry Requirement, but with relevant prior learning/work experience, will have to undergo written/oral assessment and be endorsed by the applicant’s employer.

course_title: Big Data, Cloud Computing and Machine Learning
course_title_cleaned: Big Data, Cloud Computing and Machine Learning
course_objective: FIN559 Big Data, Cloud Computing and Machine learning provides an overview of computing and cloud technology that brings disruptive changes to various businesses including financial services. It starts with providing a foundational understanding of big data processing framework and approaches, and follows by introducing relevant tools to students through case studies and hands-on training. The course then examines the core elements of cloud computing, the different types of clouds, and the risk and security issues in cloud computing. It provides a framework for selecting the optimal combination of cloud technology to meet business requirements. Furthermore, the course introduces machine learning, covering both supervised and unsupervised algorithms. It discusses biasvariance trade-off for selecting the appropriate models and introduces neural networks and convolutional neural networks. Lastly the course discusses the applications of artificial intelligence and machine learning via case studies.
course_learning_outcomes:
1. Examine the challenges in big data computing and evaluate the big-data computing framework.
2. Appraise approaches to resolve big-data computing issues.
3. Assess core elements of cloud computing and different types of clouds.
4. Appraise risk management plans for cloud computing. 
5. Evaluate IaaS, PaaS and SaaS technology.
6. Assess supervised learning and unsupervised learning.
7. Evaluate neural networks and convolutional neural networks.
8. Construct smart solution based on big-data computing.
9. Formulate calculation for practicing cloud economics.
10. Implement cloud computing using open source software.
11. Design and develop machine learning applications.
course_entry_req: Bachelor Degree
full_course_desc:
# course provider
SINGAPORE UNIVERSITY OF SOCIAL SCIENCES

Big Data, Cloud Computing and Machine Learning

# course objective
FIN559 Big Data, Cloud Computing and Machine learning provides an overview of computing and cloud technology that brings disruptive changes to various businesses including financial services. It starts with providing a foundational understanding of big data processing framework and approaches, and follows by introducing relevant tools to students through case studies and hands-on training. The course then examines the core elements of cloud computing, the different types of clouds, and the risk and security issues in cloud computing. It provides a framework for selecting the optimal combination of cloud technology to meet business requirements. Furthermore, the course introduces machine learning, covering both supervised and unsupervised algorithms. It discusses biasvariance trade-off for selecting the appropriate models and introduces neural networks and convolutional neural networks. Lastly the course discusses the applications of artificial intelligence and machine learning via case studies.

# course learning outcomes
1. Examine the challenges in big data computing and evaluate the big-data computing framework.
2. Appraise approaches to resolve big-data computing issues.
3. Assess core elements of cloud computing and different types of clouds.
4. Appraise risk management plans for cloud computing.

course_title: Digital Photography Technology
course_title_cleaned: Digital Photography Technology
course_objective: Digital photography enables still images to be stored without deterioration, compressed for saving storage speed, electronically transfered to another viewer at long distance and to be maniputated to give more enhanced images. Students are to bring a digital camera to class (compact point-and-shoot or digital single lens reflex; not mobile phone camera) to gain hands-on experience on how to use the camera.

course_title: (HCIC/CCP) Identify How Children (Birth to Age 3) Learn and Develop
course_title_cleaned: (HCIC CCP) Identify How Children (Birth to Age 3) Learn and Develop
course_objective: Knowing about young infants and toddlers’ growth and development is essential for educarers to work with young children. This module explores on the principles of infant and toddler development and young children’s patterns and sequences of development. Emphasis is placed on the study of the physical, motor, social, emotional, language and cognitive development of the very young child. Studying child development theory will help educarers to plan activities and experiences to support young children’s development.
course_learning_outcomes:
1. The ability to understand:
 Developmental theories
 Different areas of children’s growth and development
 Expected milestones (developmental stages) across different aspects of children’s growth and development
 The relevant Curriculum Frameworks utilised in Singapore
 Factors that contribute to children’s growth, well-being, learning and development

2. The ability to:
 Apply understanding of developmental stages of children from birth to 18 months to guide care-giving practice
 Apply understanding of contemporary theories and literature to support the growth, well-being, learning and development of each child
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have:
a. Minimum Secondary 2* or minimum 8 years of formal education * and
b. At least an average SOA 4 in the WPL series

*Official documents are required to show completion of 8 years of education. Medium of instruction is to
be in English.

course_title: (PDECCE-T) Apply Classroom Management Strategies, and Strategies to Observe and Document Children’s learning
course_title_cleaned: (PDECCE-T) Apply Classroom Management Strategies, and Strategies to Observe and Document Children’s learning
course_objective: This module focuses the utilisation of observations and documentations of children’s learning and development, to gain an in-depth understanding of each child, develop appropriate activities and create an environment that is conducive to teaching and learning. It also includes responding to questions from colleagues and families about children’s behaviour, maintaining confidentiality of young children and their families and collaborating with colleagues to assess impact of observation and documentation techniques adopted.  A broad set of child observations skills and ways to conduct and interpret a variety of means of child assessment, both formal and informal will be covered. Methods of assessment will include systematic observations, use of screening instruments, interviewing techniques, rating scales, portfolios and anecdotal records.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of the module, participants should have:

1. The ability to understand:
a. Theories and expected milestones (developmental stages) across different areas of children’s growth and development
b. The importance of observing and documenting children’s learning
c. Types of observation techniques
d. The purpose of different types of observation and documentation of children’s learning
e. Approaches to analyse and interpret observations and documentations of children’s learning
f. The importance of maintaining the confidentiality of young children and their families
g. Demonstrate abilities to communicate with parents, colleagues and other professional persons about individual children.
h. Demonstrate use of observation data for curriculum planning and individual educational programmes.

2. The ability to:
a. Utilise observations and documentation of children’s learning and development to inform practice
b. Gain an in-depth understanding of each child
c. Support the planning process and develop appropriate activities based on observations of children in the group
course_entry_req:
Applicants should have:

*  5 GCE ‘O’ level credits including a grade C6 in GCE ‘O’ level English Language OR Any English Language Acceptable Alternatives
OR
*  10 years of formal education in English as a medium of instruction and passed state exam with credits in 5 different subjects OR required to pass English Language
OR
*  Degree with English as medium of instruction from state recognised university OR required to pass English Language Acceptable Alternatives

course_title: WSQ Workplace Safety and Health for Food & Beverage Operations (Classroom & Asynchronous)
course_title_cleaned: WSQ Workplace Safety and Health for Food & Beverage Operations (Classroom & Asynchronous)
course_objective: To ensure experienced/inexperienced staff are aware of the importance of workplace hazards, so as to stay safe and reduce the incidences of injuries and accidents, while staying abreast with government safety regulations and policies.
course_learning_outcomes: Imparting the importance of Workplace Safety and Health to F&B personnel, enabling them to identify hazards and prevent accidents and injuries. This Course focuses on aspects of workplace safety and health in the F&B industry, together with current government safety regulations and policies.
course_entry_req:
• Academic requirements - Admission is on the basis of academic merit where students have GCE N OR O OR NITEC levels with at least 1 pass, or WSQ WPLN proficiency Level 5
• Industry experience - where possible, or in the absence of suitable academic requirements, students with a demonstrated attitude, skills and knowledge, developed through industry experience of 1 years may be suitable. Industries include Tourism,Hospitality, F&B, Catering Services.
• Interest and passion in the Tourism, Hospitality, F&B or Catering Services industry
• Due to the nature of vocational training for the F&B industry, students often commence study once they have already gained years of experience in the industry. The students may or may not have satisfied the minimum academic requirements, however their industry experience is commensurate or even higher than these requirements. In these instances, the Head of Academic may approve their enrolment on a case-by-case basis.

course_title_cleaned: Systems Concepts (in MC in System Thinking & Methods in Part-time Diploma in Engineering (Operations & Systems Management))
course_objective: This subject provides an overview of systems thinking concepts, including tools such as “causal loop diagrams” and “systems archetypes”. Students will be introduced to techniques which will enable them to look at problems and issues from a systems perspective so as to be able to design effective interventions.
course_learning_outcomes: Be empowered to boost the productivity and service levels of your organisation! In this course, you will learn process and service improvement techniques, logistics management, decision analysis, systems thinking, as well as ways to  manage projects and organisational development.

course_title: Qualitative Interviewing
course_title_cleaned: Qualitative Interviewing
course_objective: This course gives an introduction to the method and practical hands-on experience in designing and conducting interviews. Learners will learn the differences between quantitative and qualitative methods of interviewing, as well as gain an understanding of the different types of interviews, sampling, recruitment and how to craft questions. Learners will explore ways of establishing rapport and ways to get interviews done. Finally, this course also explores the analysis of data and how to present them.
course_learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, learners will be able to:
1.	Describe and identify the differences between quantitative and qualitative methods of interviewing
2.	Explain the ethical considerations, reflexivity and accountability surrounding interviews
3.	Craft interview questions
4.	Apply good pacing techniques and establish rapport with interviewees
5.	Analyse and present data clearly
